{"reviewerID": "AYOO12C9Y2T95", "asin": "B00005M987", "reviewerName": "Greg Brady \"columbusboy\"", "helpful": [2, 2], "reviewText": "Michelle Branch is touted as a \"real\" artist by her supporters because she writes her own songs and plays guitar (as well as keyboards according to the liners).Realistically, the guitar played here isn't necessarily particularly inspiring though it is competent. The songs are decent if not in the caliber of female singer-songwriter forebears like Carole King or Carly Simon (though, to be fair, Branch is 14...King's first classic [\"Will You Love Me Tomorrow?\"] was written at age 19 and Simon's 1st great [\"That's the Way I've Always Heard it Should Be\"] at 25.) Probably she most often comes across as \"Alanis Morisette-lite\": angst without anger but every bit as slickly produced as \"Jagged Little Pills\" was.HIGHLIGHTS:\"Everywhere\" is one of the better written songs on the album. It's Branch talking to her \"Mr. Right\"...whoever he may be...and hoping he's looking for her,too, wrapped tight in snappy guitar-based pop-rock. (\"'Cause you're everywhere to me/And when I close my eyes it's you I see/You're everything I know that makes me believe/I'm not alone\") \"All You Wanted\" is catchy pop. \"Something to Sleep to\" is the aftermath of first time sex. (\"In my mind/Everything we did was right/Open your eyes/I'll still be by your side\") Branch approximates Sheryl Crow (indeed she opened for Crow on tour) for \"If Only She Knew\" where she pines for an ex-love who's in the middle of a messy breakup (\"Your heart is in your throat and I'm speaking my mind/Though it looks as if it's over/I'm still not over you\"). \"Goodbye to You\" is a great tune, but a bit oversung (the phony emoting at the end of the line \"deep down in my soul-uh\" is a prime example). \"Drop in the Ocean\" closes the album on a high note with a surprising arrangement that veers from a stark ballad to a flat out techno beat.LOWS:\"You Get Me\" COULD have been a good song because longing for understanding is something everyone feels, but Branch sabotages it with a bunch of cliches and the giggle that starts the track. Producer John Shanks also uses 'of the moment' electronic voice-in-a-can effects that ensure the song will date almost immediately. \"Sweet Misery\" is too coated with synths and production tricks to come across as sincere.BOTTOM LINE:If all you want is catchy pop that's really hummable, she fills the bill. Certainly there's more soul baring going on in these songs than a multitude of recent young musical wunderkinds. (think Aaron Carter or Lil Bow Wow). But the songs are still a bit lightweight to be ones you'll continue to play years from now. Branch is young, though, so I'm hoping continued work on her writing (and the vocal maturity that will come with more age and performance) and not so much glossy production will mean great pieces of art in the future.3 1/2 stars", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Not outstanding yet but give her time", "unixReviewTime": 1114560000, "reviewTime": "04 27, 2005"}

{"reviewerID": "A2B9Y0WXNSN17U", "asin": "B00005NKYQ", "reviewerName": "doomsdayer520", "helpful": [2, 2], "reviewText": "Tori Amos has reached the point in her career where she has sufficient devotion from the fans and critics to allow her to do some offbeat experimenting. The point of this album is to work with songs written from a strongly male point of view, and reinterpret them in a female fashion. You gotta love Tori for taking a risk like this, because she doesn't even change the gender of the narrator in these songs, which leads to many mind-boggling and creepy moments. Unfortunately, it seems that Tori selected most of these songs for their lyrical concepts, rather than any musical merit. This is unfortunate, because this isn't a book of poetry, but music that you have to listen to. Many of these songs were originally straight rock or hard rock, and have been very awkwardly transformed to Tori's style. About the only song on this album with ear-catching music is &quot;Strange Little Girl,&quot; (which I think is by the new wave band Sad Caf&eacute;, but I'm not sure) and maybe &quot;Time&quot; and &quot;New Age&quot; (Tom Waits and Lou Reed respectively). Another catchy tune is 10cc's &quot;I'm Not In Love&quot; in which Tori transforms the sappy soft-rock of the original into a creepy and obsessive dirge.Otherwise, most of the music on this album doesn't work. Depeche Mode's &quot;Enjoy the Silence&quot; is very boring as a basic piano ballad, and Tori's guitar rock attempt at Neil Young's &quot;Heart of Gold&quot; is noisy and almost unlistenable. The Beatles' &quot;Happiness Is a Warm Gun&quot; is transformed into a ten-minute groove with voluminous speeches by George W. Bush and other politicians, but this experiment is mostly a never-ending disaster. Tori takes another huge leap by turning Slayer's &quot;Raining Blood&quot; from speed metal to symphonic balladry, but for this to make sense, the rhythm has to be slowed down to such snail-like levels that you think the track is never going to end.Even with this problematic music, Tori does break through with some of the lyrical interpretations on this album. Joe Jackson's treatise on the challenges faced by gay males, &quot;Real Men,&quot; becomes very thought-provoking when delivered by a woman. And you can't avoid the cover of Eminem's &quot;'97 Bonnie &amp; Clyde.&quot; In the original, Eminem sounded hateful and ignorant in this song which boasts of killing his wife while his young daughter watches. But it sounds downright disturbing from Tori's sinister and condemning female perspective.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "An Admirable Experiment, But Only Partially Successful", "unixReviewTime": 1004400000, "reviewTime": "10 30, 2001"}
{"reviewerID": "A38OKIE3HRGUW0", "asin": "B00005NKYQ", "reviewerName": "_", "helpful": [1, 2], "reviewText": "Even though this new album is all cover material and nothing new from Tori, I still had to get it. Tori's version is more haunting than Eminem's original, but I will treat this song as I did the original--  one listen.  The song really doesn't offer &quot;listenable return&quot;, unless someone is trying to plot something.  The title track, &quot;Strange Little Girl(s)&quot; is very impressive. Tori basically strips the song down, simply utilizing her vocals, some quiet synth strings, and cascading adagio piano.  &quot;I'm Not In Love&quot; did not really grab me.  It is mostly a languid programmed drum beat.  If you are not entranced by Tori's voice here, you will probably frequently skip this song.  &quot;Rattlesnakes&quot; has a nice folksy-rock-sway to it.  The soothing acoustic guitar, brushing rhythms, calm Fender Rhodes, and Tori's diffused vocals definitely makes this song one of my favorites.  &quot;Time&quot; feels like a late-night small country bar recitation.  Tori returns to her piano/vocal formula, adding some lyrical optimism.  Tori continues the story recitation mode on &quot;I Don't Like Mondays&quot;, switching over to rhodes/vocal.  I really appreciate her heavenly narration and rhodes playing because it helps me find some peace in these busy days.  &quot;Raining Blood&quot; reflects strains of invocation.  I don't think that Tori has ever been as 'Gothic' as she is on this song.  If you thought &quot;97 Bonnie &amp; Clyde&quot; was unnerving, then this track will certainly give your attention a run!  &quot;Real Men&quot; offers a subtle and moot closing to this album, riddled with so much poignant intensity.If you are a dedicated Tori Amos fan, then I would suggest that you buy this album. {"reviewerID": "A26XCS3QLDJJWN", "asin": "B00005QXKE", "reviewerName": "Patrick G. Varine \"Make beats, not war, haha...\"", "helpful": [0, 0], "reviewText": "Extended-family albums don't always work too well. For evidence, look no further than Jay-Z's \"Roc La Familia\" (technically a solo album, but c'mon now...) and some of the pseudo-Wu solo releases from groups like LA the Darkman and Remedy. The reason they don't work so well? Usually it's because the extended family just isn't that talented.But with the Dungeon Family, an exception must be made. True, stars like Outkast and Goodie MOb outshine most of their colleagues. But the releases from the Dungeon Family the past few years have been very strong. Cool Breeze's \"Watch for the Hook\" had some bangin' tracks. Sleepy's Theme's \"The Vinyl Room\" was a nice chunk of laid-back funk. Even Backbone's rocky \"Concrete Law\" had some very good moments.And let's not forget that the DF has Organized Noize, one of the more adventurous and innovative production teams, manning the boards on almost every release. So \"Even in Darkness\" turns out to be exactly the what you would expect from a family reunion: there's a few relatives you don't really like, but at the end of the day, it was a good time.The front half of the album isn't as good as it could be, but interesting nonetheless. Mr. DJ of ET3 Productions handles the tracks that Organized Noize doesn't, and while his beats prove to be long on innovation, some of them distract from the vocals.It's the back half that really kicks the album into high gear, start with \"Forever Pimpin' (Never Slippin').\" A short track with a chopped string melody and some deeeeEEEEEEEp bass, Cool Breeze flips his conversational flow for a strong two minutes you can bump in the trunk anytime. The posse-cut homage \"6 Minutes\" is probably the best song on the album, with most of the Family making a brief appearance over a slammin' track.But it's the surprises that really make \"Darkness\" worth it. Bubba Sparxxx shows up on the bouncy \"White Gutz,\" whose syncopated beat sounds odd at first, but really grows on you. \"Excalibur\" and \"Rollin',\" however, use loping, 3/4 beats. The former is a heavy spiritual track, rounding out w/the entire family singing the hook, \"We are the few/the strong/the proud holders of the Excalibur.\" And the latter is some slooooooow Cadillac trunk funk with old-school horns and a nice chorus (\"Are you rooooollin'/Down the same street that I'm goooooin'/Up the same (...) that I'm foooooldin'/On a new riiiide\").There are also some strong appearances on the uptempo \"What Iz Rap?\" by the Witchdoctor and by some DF unknowns on \"Curtains.\" Overall, some tracks could be better, but this is definitely a worthwhile ride on the Trans-DF Express. It's dark, dirty, and FUNKY.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Not bad for a supergroup album", "unixReviewTime": 1007683200, "reviewTime": "12 7, 2001"}

{"reviewerID": "A18IZ5QX2PRB3C", "asin": "B00005R09Z", "reviewerName": "Michael Stack", "helpful": [1, 1], "reviewText": "A career overview of tracks selected by Robert Smith, \"Greatest Hits\" may be a bit of a misnomer, at least here in the United States, but nonetheless this proves to be a fine overview of the Cure's tenure with Fiction Records-- the only shortcoming of the piece is that as a single disc, selection had to be carefully performed and a number of critical pieces were omitted.The album opens with one of the band's early singles, the moody \"Boys Don't Cry\" and tracks their time with Fiction, from the early, somewhat bleak stuff (\"A Forest\") to the flirtations with pop (\"Close to Me\", \"Why Can't I Be You?\", \"Just Like Heaven\", breakthrough \"Friday I'm in Love\") to funky experiments (horn-laden single mix of \"Close to Me\", which is vastly superior to the album mix, \"Mixed Up\" new track \"Never Enough\") and the bleaker pieces the band's reputation centers around (\"Lovesong\").  The collection also includes a pair of new tracks-- \"Cut Here\" and \"Just Say Yes\".  Both are driven by programmed rhythms and while \"Cut Here\" is decent enough, I actually find the somewhat forced ecstacy of \"Just Say Yes\" to be downright irritating.But there is a lot missing, and with the record clocking in at only 68 minutes, there was room for a bit more-- no \"Killing An Arab\" or \"10:15 Saturday Night\" from their early days, nothing at all from \"Faith\", \"Pornography\" or \"The Top\", with several pieces from those albums being fine candidates (\"Shake Dog Shake\", \"Primary\", non-album track \"Charolotte Sometimes\", \"The Hanging Garden\" or live set feature \"One Hundred Years\") and a noticably absent \"Pictures of You\" from \"Disintegration\" (curiously, it was included on the European release of the record).  Maybe a two disc set would have served better, but certainly some of these could have been included with some songs quite frankly making me wonder why they were chosen in place of those (\"High\" for example).Still, no collection is perfect, and this one does a pretty good job at what it targets.  If you're new to the band, it's a decent overview.A final note, when the album was initially released, it included a bonus disc with acoustic renditions of all the songs on the record-- fans will want to track this one down.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "A bit thin of a career retrospective.", "unixReviewTime": 1156291200, "reviewTime": "08 23, 2006"}
{"reviewerID": "AGAMDS21PJZPK", "asin": "B00005RGL2", "reviewerName": "J. Highsmith", "helpful": [3, 4], "reviewText": "After releasing Queensbridge classics such as &quot;LA, LA&quot;, &quot;Illegal Life&quot;, Stick You&quot;, &quot;T.O.N.Y.&quot; and &quot;Closer&quot; with partner in crime Capone, Noreaga has taken a different path with his music.  N.O.R.E. has become someone that just wants to have fun and have a good time with his music.  Noreaga will never be in a best lyricist Top 20 or he will never be known for his great lyrics, but he always finds a way to get your attention.  That is Victor Santiago's niche in the rap game.  He can always get your attention.  On his debut solo CD, once &quot;Superthug&quot; was released to radio, you couldn't tell Noreaga anything because he had one of the hottest songs on the street and on radio.  If it wasn't for this hit song, the Neptunes might not even be around today and that is the truth.  Other memorable moments from his debut CD include &quot;Banned From TV&quot; w/Big Pun, Cam'ron, Nature &amp; The LOX, &quot;The Assignment&quot; w/Busta Rhymes, Spliff Star &amp; Maze, the first single, &quot;N.O.R.E.&quot;, &quot;Body In The Trunk&quot; w/Nas, and &quot;I Love My Life&quot; w/Carl Thomas.  On his second CD, &quot;Melvyn Flynt- Da Hustler&quot;, it seemed Noreaga was uninspired and that his label was trying to capitalize on the success of &quot;Superthug&quot; to soon.  Although, the first single, &quot;Oh No&quot; was prodcued by The Neptunes and was a success, the rest of the CD was very lackluster.  Other than &quot;Sometimes&quot;, which was a tribute to his late father,  the CD was filled with filler material.  Once his partner Capone returned home after being incarcerated they recorded their last CD for Tommy Boy records entitled &quot;The Reunion&quot;.  This reminded me of the Noreaga that I expected from his &quot;War Report&quot; days.  Songs like &quot;Bang Bang&quot; w/Foxy Brown, &quot;Phonetime&quot;, &quot;Invincible&quot; where he even admits that &quot;Melvyn Flynt&quot; was wack, &quot;B EZ&quot; w/Nas, and &quot;Y'all Don't Wanna&quot; were songs worth hearing from the Queens duo.  Now signed to Def Jam Records, Noreaga is here for a fresh start.  The switching of labels has done Noreaga some good and the results are pretty good.  First of all, some of the material is outdated, the CD's official 1st single, &quot;Grimey&quot; was actually released on the &quot;Violator 2&quot; CD.  The Neptunes drop a nasty beat and the words flow from Noreaga's voice like he has been working with The Neptunes since birth.  Although many fans may be tired of hearing Noreaga over The Neptunes' beats, that's when he is at his best.  The 2nd single from &quot;God's Favorite&quot;, &quot;Nothin'&quot; is another Neptunes track and is definitely all over radio and the club scene at this time.  He won't win any points for originality, but this formula seems to work.  &quot;Live My Life&quot; w/Ja Rule was supposed to be the 2nd single but after receiving a lukewarm reception from radio stations, Def Jam decided to go back to the drawing board, which was smart.  &quot;Nothin'&quot; will definitely get Noreaga the gold plaque that he is accustomed to getting.  Other noteworthy tracks include, &quot;Full Mode&quot;, which will definitely be the next single after &quot;Nothin&quot; wears out its welcome, &quot;Head Bussa&quot;, the remix of the Swizz Beats track, &quot;Nahmeanuheard&quot; w/Cam'ron, Fat Joe, Cassidy &amp; Capone, &quot;Black Clouds&quot; and &quot;Mr. CEO&quot;.  I agree with reviewer anthony humphrey on his opinions about the song &quot;Big D&quot;.  This song was just a bad idea and probably just a way to get Akinyele on the CD.  We don't need to hear Noreaga spit Spice channel type rhymes.  Other filler tracks include &quot;Wanna Be Like Him&quot; w/Mashonda and &quot;Banned From Another Club&quot;.  &quot;Consider This&quot; w/Kelis has a catchy beat but the song is ruined when Noreaga starts talking about his &quot;merry mack, all dressed in black&quot;.  I mean, how unoriginal is that.  &quot;Love Ya Moms&quot; was a good idea and is a good track, altogether.  Overall, Noreaga has definitely showed improvement since his last solo offering.  After a Def Jam Capone N Noreaga CD, Noreaga might have somethiing for us the fourth time around.  He needs to improve on his subject matter but as long as he has good producers around him, he will always make some kind of impact on the rap game.  Also, check out Track 19, &quot;The Life Of A... (Gangsta)&quot;, the bonus track with Capone &amp; Chinky.  It is worth listening to. {"reviewerID": "AFTN9ZLB22PSZ", "asin": "B00005RZWJ", "reviewerName": "ctrx", "helpful": [3, 4], "reviewText": "Warren G has always been and will always be among my favorite hip hop artists, one of the West Coast's most ingenious producing minds. His 2001 album \"The Return of the Regulator\" is his weakest effort, but one that's still worth a listen for his fans in my mind. This album succeeds in most of the areas that his earlier efforts do, but fails in a few notable areas. His first three albums, 1994's classicRegulate...G Funk Era, 1997'sTake a Look Over Your Shoulder, and 1999'sI Want It Allwere all marked by his wonderful production, his signature g-funk sound with rich instrumentation, laidback vibes and a soulful, slow-rolling feel that evoked images of his sunny California home. On \"The Return of the Regulator,\" the sound is a little different, adjusting to the evolving West Coast sound following Dr. Dre's influential2001album. The beats are generally more upbeat and less smooth than before. Personally I find the beats here to be weaker than on any of his other LPs, but his musical talent remains. He still fills his tracks with clever arrangements, and they're always catchy, even if they don't have the irresistable soulfulness he's known for.\"The Return of the Regulator\" has many good songs, but few really great ones. Time and time again, Warren has proven able to craft true anthems and classic songs, and there are none to be found on this effort. That's not to say it's not a solid album though, because there aren't any noticeably bad songs either. Overall, it's just not as memorable an album. Part of this is due to the subject matter. Warren's always been a producer first and a rapper second, but this is brought to the forefront here. Usually, he makes do by rapping about his Long Beach, California hometown and reminiscing over growing up, and his likable character makes his verses appealing. This doesn't happen enough here, and his crew of guests too often lacks the big names of his earlier albums, replacing them with more ordinary MCs like Mista Grimm, Boss Hogg and Damone. \"The Return of the Regulator\" is Warren G's weakest album, but despite its flaws it still showcases his talent as a producer and artist.The album opens with a full-length intro, which consists of a simple, bouncy beat, Warren's commentary, and a verse by Damone. \"Lookin' at You\" is an eerie Dr. Dre production with an appearance from Ms. Toi on vocals, Warren's verses are a bit lackluster but it's a solid cut. The joyful-sounding \"Here Comes Another Hit\" features Nate Dogg on the hook and a verse from Mista Grimm for an early, energetic highlight. \"Somethin' to Bounce To\" is also upbeat and sunny, Soopafly and Warren display nice chemistry without any substantial lyricism. \"This Gangsta S... Is Too Much\" isn't quite as memorable, despite a cool beat and guest by Butch Cassidy. \"Young Locs Slow Down\" is probably the best song, featuring Butch Cassidy at his eerie best and WC with a nice guest as well. The beat is somber, catchy, and clever, using a twangy guitar line. The album takes a turn for the worse at this point, beginning with \"Speed Dreamin',\" an awkward collabo with George Clinton and Mista Grimm, and \"Yo' Sassy Ways,\" a forgettable 213 collabo. After the okay posse cut \"It Ain't Nothin' Wrong With U\" comes one of my favorites, \"Ghetto Village.\" This song makes use of a famous Stevie Wonder sample, and Warren speaks of growing up in his Long Beach neighborhood over a clever laidback beat. \"They Lovin' Me Now\" is cool, but like too much on this album, not substantial enough to be truly memorable. \"Streets of LBC\" is likably unsettling, and \"G-Funk Is Here to Stay\" is alright but just doesn't quite work. The album closes with a deep, well-executed ode to Warren's mother called \"Keepin' It Strong.\" It's a more soulful, somber version of \"Ola Mae\" fromI Want It All.\"The Return of the Regulator\" has a few flaws, but the catchy production for the most part makes it a solid album that I recommend to his fans. The title and cover art recall his classic debut, and this album would never be compared to it. I highly recommend each of his other LPs, and this one should only be owned by those who already own and love his other four. If not for the wonderful quality of his earlier records, this album would be remembered as a better effort.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Warren's weakest effort, still worth a listen", "unixReviewTime": 1195689600, "reviewTime": "11 22, 2007"}

{"reviewerID": "A2Q8BZMIXLLCNG", "asin": "B00005TPKC", "reviewerName": "Peter Marinari", "helpful": [1, 1], "reviewText": "Alanis has never failed to shock and thrill the listening public, but on Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie it became clear that she would be happy unloading her thoughts on us wholesale over any riff that would stand under her lyrical weight. Either through the grace of God or the co-writing/production of Glen Ballard (or both), it overwhelmingly worked in its unorthodox way. However, on Under Rug Swept it has gone terribly out of control. It dominates almost every song, all of which sound unusually glossy when compared to Alanis's previous work. It's not that there's nothing wrong with turning from a critical darling (back) to a shimmery popstress, but i don't have to like it. Glen Ballard, where did you go?It isn't that Alanis Morissette's third American studio effort is terrible, it's just that it's unrefined... and it's hard not draw a connection from there to her suddenly solo writing and production duties. Under Rug Swept honestly sounds as though Alanis walked into the studio and proceeded to record without ever pausing to edit any lyrical aspect of her songs. Witness the rambly nonsense of \"21 Things I Want In A Lover,\" the awkward phrasing of the otherwise excellent \"Hands Clean,\" and the altogether ill-advised thunder of \"A Man.\" The unusual indisputable hits that we've come to expect are entirely absent, unless you count the epilectic electric guitars of kiss-off \"Narcissus,\" which verge very closely on being annoying.There are two songs on this disc that prove that Alanis is still a force to be reckoned with. \"So Unsexy\" combines a simple two-measure guitar riff with an equally simple bass line, and upon these strong foundations Alanis vents her unedited spleen in the effective fashion that we've come to expect from her; its at once sweet and defiant, and totally catchy. \"Flinch\" is slowly strummed classic, loaded with real couplets and an actual narrative. For just a track it hijacks the pop production of the disc for its own purposes, and comes out as the plainest and best heartbreak ballad in Alanis's entire catalogue.Hearing this pair of tunes makes it clear that there are still good songs to be heard from our erstwhile Canadian friend; obviously someone just has to figure out how to whittle them down after they effortlessly flow out of her.", "overall": 2.0, "summary": "Under Rug Swept? Really? Could we leave it there?", "unixReviewTime": 1047772800, "reviewTime": "03 16, 2003"}

{"reviewerID": "A2DVFHG099GUGE", "asin": "B000060O2C", "reviewerName": "sauerkraut", "helpful": [1, 1], "reviewText": "This is Vandenberg's self-titled debut album that was released in 1982.  It has got nine tracks that are in a straight-ahead hard rock musical direction.  One of these cuts--\"Burning Heart\"--is a power ballad.  The album's songwriting, musicianship, and sound quality are solid.  Bert Heerink is a good, spirited, smooth-sounding vocalist.  Jos Zoomer's drumming sounds nice in the mix, too.  Adrian Vandenberg does not disappoint in the guitar playing department, either.  The songs that I consider to be favorites are \"Your Love Is in Vain,\" \"Wait,\" and \"Burning Heart.\"  Heerink pulls off a solid singing performance on the fun \"Your Love Is in Vain.\"  The engaging, well-written \"Wait\" is a slow burner that is characterized by a taut, pleasing guitar riff from Vandenberg and a remarkable chorus.  \"Burning Heart\" is an unforgettable gem of a composition with its beginning which consists solely of Vandenberg's indelible guitar work.  Heerink's vocals are also memorable and arresting along with the song's refrain.  The CD insert includes a color photo of the band and the lyrics to the songs.  The CD is just over 37 minutes.  This is a recommendable piece of work.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "A good album", "unixReviewTime": 1235779200, "reviewTime": "02 28, 2009"}

{"reviewerID": "A2WKKTVYS5H61M", "asin": "B0000634ID", "reviewerName": "Mecca Egypt", "helpful": [7, 8], "reviewText": "Gold Mind's newest excavation, Tweet, gives us a taste of honey-drenched soul on her debut album Southern Hummingbird. Helmed by the lead single \"Oops (Oh My),\" a late-night R&B; heater about the joys of \"self-love,\" one might figure the rest of her album is full of jerky, overproduced Missy Elliott numbers.This is not the case.The album takes its cue more from the classic soul of the '70s and '80s than modern R&B; with surprising results. The album lovingly grooves along with rich vocals, soulful ballads and acoustic underpinnings.Instrumentation and musicianship take a refreshing front seat over heavily produced, trendy R&B.; Filled with impressive gems and intoxicating rhythms, there's a song for almost every melodic mood. \"Best Friend\" is a reclined slow jam that pares up the laid-back, no fuss stylings of Tweet to the warmth of neo-soulite Bilal.The range of Southern Hummingbird is remarkably multifaceted; from the stripped-down microphone & guitar vibe of \"Motel\" to the heartbreaking dark of \"Drunk\" which howls with carousing abandon (\"I'd rather be drunk on a cloud far away from here than sober\") and inebriating to-and-fro melody. There's a foray into early '80s synth-soul with the old school-esque jam \"Make Ur Move,\" a throwback to the roller discos and poplockers of the era of excess and even tiptoes into honky-tonk country (\"Complain\").Largely the artist herself culls most of the album's more potent material. Her more than 10 years toiling as an aspiring solo artist have paid off: Her skills as a songwriter, drummer and acoustic guitarist are impressively detailed here.More complex than anything that can currently be offered up by a trio of \"bootylicious\" singers or a girl that's not yet a woman, Tweet's voice exhibits a unique redolence similar to the soul sirens of the seventies - Minnie Riperton, Evelyn Champagne King and Angela Bofill - rather than keeping up with the interchangeable chicks featured on the hook of a rap track.She is distinctive amongst the crowded school of R&B; fish. Her album is one that opts to lead by being lyrically open and musically adventurous. An old school-inspired record brimming with new school promise, Southern Hummingbird is the diary of an emerging musical talent on the rise.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Tweet excavates a suprisingly good debut", "unixReviewTime": 1017705600, "reviewTime": "04 2, 2002"}

{"reviewerID": "A1OC3D2LGBFDJ4", "asin": "B0000665WR", "reviewerName": "CrazyWhacko_88 \"Music Addict\"", "helpful": [1, 1], "reviewText": "In celebration of Clipse's critically acclaimed 2006 sophomore album, \"Hell Hath No Fury\", I've decided to check out \"Lord Willin'\", the supposably forgotten debut album of rapping brothers Pusha T & Malice. Since I haven't listened to \"Hell Hath No Fury\" just yet, I can't compare it to this debut album, but \"Lord Willin'\" stands on its own as a satisfying, but flawed, record.If there's anything that makes \"Lord Willin'\" stand out from other average Hip-Hop albums, it's The Neptunes, who produce the album in its entirety. The beats are harder and far more thrilling and invigorating than the majority of their more recent efforts, especially on the minimalist-beat-driven hustler's anthem \"Grindin'\" & \"Young Boy\", a lyrically reflective club jam driven by Pharrell William's lively hook and bombastic Funk-inflected horns strangely -if not ironically- reminiscent of Beyonce's R&B;/Funk club jam \"Work It Out\", another Neptunes concoction.Unfortunately, one of the album's problems lies with Clipse themselves. There's no denying the fact that the two are strong rappers -their vocal delivery is cold, harsh, strong, fearless and emotionless- but it's hard to tell Malice & Pusha T apart due to their similar flows and vocals. That doesn't mean that they can't write good lyrics - songs like the aforementioned \"Grindin'\", the gloomy, anthemic \"Virginia\" and the straightforward album standout \"Cot Damn\" (feat. Pharrell Williams as hook singer and everyone else -Ab-Liva & Roscoe P Coldchain- as rappers) prove otherwise, while many of the other album's tracks display their knack for clever and inventive wordplay.It is at this point, however, that we realise the album's second fundamental flaw - its lack of substance. Songs like the admittedly addictive \"When The Last Time\" -featuring Pharrell Williams as hook rapper & Kelis as severely underused R&B; songstress, who is restricted to a simple vocal refrain on the song's bridge over The Neptunes' heavy synths and faint guitar loop- & the self-explanatory \"Ego\" resort to the ways of misogyny, commercialism and materialism that has rapidly deteriorated modern-day Hip-Hop, while other songs like \"Ma, I Don't Love Her\" (feat. another underutilised R&B; singer, Faith Evans) & \"Gangsta Lean\" (feat. Pharrell as -you guessed it!- hook singer) are virtually devoid of true emotion or sentiment.The final problem I have with this album is the excess guest appearances. Not only do Clipse lack emotion or passion in their delivery, but they also lack any form of personality or individuality that could've otherwise separated them apart from not only each other, but the album's other truckload of guest artists. Whether or not Pharrell Williams is credited as an official guest artist is of little concern, since he drops a lively contribution (mainly a hook) on almost all of the tracks on the album. While that may be good for the memorability factor or the quality of the actual tracks, it also highlights the Clipse's inability to consistently craft solid, infectious hooks. Other guests include all of the aforementioned artists (Ab-Liva, Roscoe P Coldchain, Kelis, Pharrell Williams, Faith Evans), Famlay (\"Famlay Freestyle\"), Fabolous (\"Comedy Central\", where is style is easily more recognizable), Jermaine Dupri (\"Lets Talk About It\") and Jadakiss & Styles P of the Lox (\"I'm Not You\"). The two remixes of \"Grindin'\" also feature NO.R.E., Baby & Lil' Wayne on the first remix, while Sean Paul, Kardinal Offishall & Bless appear on the latter.As a whole, this is a solid debut, but is too flawed to be deemed a classic. The Clipse should consider themselves lucky to have The Neptunes on their side because they, along with Kelis, tend to bring the best out of the production duo. 3 stars!5 Best Tracks (IMO) (In No Order):\"Grindin'\" (original version)\"Virginia\"\"Cot Damn\"\"Young Boy\"\"Comedy Central\"", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "\"Lord Willin'\" - Neptunes Please, The Clipse Disappoint, Pharrell's Omnipresent & Guests Are Heavy", "unixReviewTime": 1167004800, "reviewTime": "12 25, 2006"}

Her sound was hyped to be a cosmic, eccentric blend between spaced out poetry and World sounds mixed with rock and hip hop flourishes. Plus she was a former background singer for Soul II Soul as well as James Brown and David Bowie. And...to add icing to the cake, she's signed by Clive Davis to his J Records imprint. {"reviewerID": "A1SC682D5FO0KC", "asin": "B00006IK1C", "reviewerName": "Matthew Schwarz", "helpful": [2, 2], "reviewText": "After Iron Maiden's seven albums in the 80s, they pretty much were in a league of their own musically.  When this came out I snatched it up, and was very surprised that it was nothing like I expected.  Iron Maiden, and Bruce with them, had a powerful, mystical, and intelligent style that set them apart, where this album (and, to a lesser degree, the Iron Maiden albums that followed it) sounded more like mainstream hard rock/metal.  I expected more from Bruce, the metal genius who provided us with songs like \"Revelations\" and \"Powerslave\", but it seems that after having such high quality stuff with Maiden, here he was just having a bit of fun.And, on that count, it works.  It's not epic or as musically intricate as Iron Maiden, but there's some good hard/rock metal here, and although some of the lyrics are more humorous/innuendo-ish (along the lines of AC/DC or Aerosmith), there's also some down-to-earth introspective lyrics about life and the world around him.  So, don't buy it expecting Iron Maiden, but it's certainly an enjoyable and listenable album. {"reviewerID": "A3FWHXSZSTKFIU", "asin": "B00006ISBT", "reviewerName": "Scott Woods", "helpful": [51, 77], "reviewText": "Coming off of a classic first album, we see that Sister Arie remains a fine musician/singer and the music on this new disc definitely showcases her talents on these fronts.  The grooves swing, the album is mixed incredibly tight and the arrangements are great. The changes are solid and the vocals even better than on her first record.But you know how an artist's intentions can be TOO clear?  The messages too in-your-face?  How a poem or song or book can make you TOO conscious of the fact that you're partaking in listening or reading and not simply allowing the art to flow over you and take you away?  That's what's wrong here.The problem I have is with the lyrics: they're WAY too preachy.I thought that the music was so well-done that I would be able to circumvent the lyrics here and there just to have something to groove to like I do with half the stuff on the radio, but that's turned out to not be the case.  A song will come in with a great beat, great harmonizing and great arrangements for about 20 seconds and then you're inundated with Sunday School-level lessons for three minutes.  Where's the risk-taking of \"Brown Skin\" or the gutsy self-confidence of \"Video\"?  Where's the humanity of \"Ready for Love\" or the philisophical punch of \"I See God In You\"?  It's just not there this time around.  It's almost as if she's heard so many people tell her that her first record was so positive that it's hamstrung her from taking too many chances on this record with the messages.  This album is cursed with the kind of \"We Are the World\" heavy-handedness that ruined the better part of the Lauryn Hill live record earlier this year.Great playing mired in WAY heavy-handed and too-simple lyrics.  The musical equivalent of an Iyanla Vanzant seminar, which is unfortunate because her first album was a classic and a much-needed shot in the arm of a musical arena saturated with negativity.  This, however, is too far at the other end of the love/hate spectrum.  If I wanted a gospel album, I'd have bought a gospel album.  She's clearly fallen in love since the last record as well, which is fine, but because of that there's a lot of not-great sap here too.  Not even racy, midnight-mood, slow-jammy sap...it's just simplistic I'm-in-love type stuff that, lyrically, you could get anywhere.The shining track here is \"The One\" but it's not enough to justify buying the record if you liked the risks and confidence of her first record. {"reviewerID": "A68GUAHPBDUN", "asin": "B00006ZCFH", "reviewerName": "Andrew Jacob", "helpful": [23, 31], "reviewText": "I think Erykah Badu says it best: \"Back in the day when things were cool\"After the success of \"Love of my life [an ode to hip hop]\" off  the \"Brown Sugar\" Soundtrack, Ms. Badu comes back with her third studio offering, World Wide Underground. Erykah Badu was always known to reinvent herself from each album, almost her way of showing you that she's growing. Well... Maybe she grew too much, because this EP is in many ways a disappointment. One of the main problems that affect this album is the lyrics. The lyrics to \"I Want You\", although has it's guilty-pleasure of a rhythm, becomes very repetitive. Another problem lies in this new style of Erykah's. Erykah has now taken it to herself to make her songs as long (or in some cases, short, almost incomplete) as possible; This is her way of not feeling \"restricted\" &amp; not being \"obligated\" to limit her songs to 4 minutes. \"I Want You\" is about 11 minutes long, and most of it, Erykah is just stretching out the hook. I wouldn't mind if an 11-minute version of a song appeared on a live album, since it sometimes takes time to set a vibe, but I expect better quality version on a studio version. The major problem is the length of the album as a whole. Excluding the pointless intro &amp; outro, \"World Keeps turnin'\", this album only contains 8 tracks: \"Think Twice\" is basically a filler, \"Love of My Life Worldwide\" is a horrible, and unnecessary remix, &amp; \"Steady on the Grind\" sounds like the M1 (of Dead Prez) version of Me'Shell Ndeg&eacute;Ocello's \"Dead N**** Blvd.\", just with Erykah singing the hook. \"Woo\" would've worked much better as the intro instead of &quot;World Keeps Turnin'&quot;, since it's a medley of Erykah singing reminiscent lyrics, giving shout outs (with people she toured with), &amp; chanting, \"woo!\" And although I do like the song \"Danger (Block On Lock)\", there something in me that wants to hate it, because this is yet another song where Erykah tries to remind us of her debut, \"Baduizm\"; On Mama's Gun, There is the track \"... &amp; On\", which is obviously part two of \"On &amp; On\", and now it's \"Danger\", part two of \"Other Side Of The Game\". It's a little immature, and I'm beginning to think that Erykah can't let go of her past. She should take her own advice: No Turning Back (\"My Life\", Mama's Gun)But there is one song I like very well; the funky \"Bump It\" (although she some-what ruins it with the unnecessary echoing-vocal-harmonizing at about 5:35, the song is 8:51)When it comes down to it, Erykah slacked off on this album, especially with the lyrics. She has this new \"let things flow\" attitude that just isn't cutting it. The only good tracks are \"Bump It\", \"Woo\", &amp; \"Danger\". They all possess that Funk... but they're not even all that great, aightt-at best. There are guilty pleasures like \"I Want You\" &amp; \"Back in the day\", but their replay values seem very low. It seems that all the songs with at least a bit of substance are the shortest, while the low quality tracks seem to last forever. Also, at times, it seems like Erykah and her crew just got a new mix board with sound effects, and started to record the stuff they were experimenting with (listen to the outro). There isn't a sufficient amount of satisfying songs, leaving this album to feel incomplete. Still, Erykah Badu is very talented, and if you want to hear her best works, get \"Mama's Gun\"", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "&quot;Think Twice&quot;", "unixReviewTime": 1063929600, "reviewTime": "09 19, 2003"}
{"reviewerID": "A1X0ZPO04DUJT2", "asin": "B00006ZCFH", "reviewerName": "Michael Jones", "helpful": [12, 15], "reviewText": "Okay, no doubt this review will either 1)get ignored or 2)get a bunch of \"I did not find this review helpful\" votes. But, whatever.I'll say up front, I am a fan of Erykah Badu. I own everything she's ever released. In fact, I bought \"Worldwide Underground\" as soon as it dropped without having heard a note on it.I'm sad to say, though, that I was a little disappointed.Yes, I GET that it's transitional. And I GET that she was trying to experiment, which is admirable. And I GET that she wanted to expand the parameters of  Neo-Soul, both in terms of sonic textures and running times (\"I Need You\" and \"Bump It\" clock-in at around 10 minutes each.) And in some ways, it reminds me a bit of albums like Isaac Hayes' \"Hot Buttered Soul,\" where there's only a handful of tracks and the grooves unfold sometimes over the course of fifteen-twenty minutes. But this EP (it's only 10 songs deep) struggles because of lack of focus.Don't get me wrong, there are some great ideas and moments on here. The last couple of minutes of \"Bump It\" where Badu vocalizes with Karon Wheeler and Zap Mama are mesmerizing. And \"Back in the Day (Puff)\" was one of the best songs of 2003, hands-down--it hits you from the beginning with a tight beat, catchy hook, and clever vocals.  It's signature Erykah Badu. Plus, the new version of \"Love of My Life\" where she freaks \"Funk You Right On Up\" by the Sequence (with Angie Stone, a.k.a. Angie B, on vocals) is flawless.  \"Think Twice\" is also so soulful that it hurts; its just a bit too truncated.But then it all kind of falls apart with the grab bag of tracks on the rest of the album, which vary between playing it super safe (\"The Grind\" and \"Danger\") and experimenting to the point of being aimless. The latter is true on \"I Need You,\" where a monotonous, one-note-played-over-a-heartbeat intro lasts almost two minutes before the groove even gets going, and then it never REALLY gets going.  Around the 8-minute mark, it dissolves into a distorted jam session, which just about the time you think will segue into a Funkadelic-type chunk o' funk, it fades out into (yet another) rehashing of \"Sometimes\" off \"Baduizm.\" (\"Woo\" probably is hot when she does it live, but here it falls flat.) And speaking of \"Baduizm,\" \"Danger\" is the other side of the other side of \"The Other Side of The Game.\" (If Neo-Soul is dead, like the cover art indicates, no use beating it to death...)Anyway, the warning is: don't expect a full-fledged album. This is more a loose mix of unfinished thoughts, clever ideas, and developing genius. It's worth buying simply for \"Back in the Day,\" if nothing else.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Good but not Great (3.5 stars)", "unixReviewTime": 1083369600, "reviewTime": "05 1, 2004"}

{"reviewerID": "A1S2IY37JU93XS", "asin": "B00006ZCFH", "reviewerName": "W. E. Phillips", "helpful": [2, 2], "reviewText": "Erykah Badu first entered the music industry in 1997 with a fresh, jazzy neo-soul sound that instantly brought critical acclaim and even comparisons to all-time greats, such as Billie Holiday and Chaka Khan. Her superb debut album, Baduizm, won her two Grammy Awards, and was soon certified triple-platinum by the RIAA. Badu's raw, soulful, and introspective sophomore album, Mama's Gun, was equally praised, and most modern R&B; fans would agree that it is a classic. Three years later came this so-called EP--which proves to be both a disclaimer and misnomer for this fifty-minute collection of ten songs--Worldwide Underground.A misnomer because EPs are not usually meant to be more than twenty-five minutes in length, a disclaimer because this experimental rough sketch is not meant to be the predecessor of Mama's Gun. This, of course, disappointed many of Erykah's fans, who had been waiting patiently for a rightful third album from the quirky singer. However, if listened to with a free mind and no expectations, Worldwide is not the huge disappointment it's been made out to be.The addictive \"Danger,\" in my honest opinion, is one of the best songs Badu has crafted in her entire career. Telling the tale of a drug dealer's ride-or-die girlfriend with a guilty conscience, the track serves as an upbeat and energetic sequel to her earlier hit single, \"Otherside of the Game.\" Over deep, thumping bass and sharp horns, Erykah plays the part with extreme skill and style. The hook-heavy, six-minute ride through the dark city never gets old to me. \"I Want You,\" about a strong (and distracting) longing for a lover, is quite a long track, clocking in at almost eleven minutes. But it still never fails to fascinate me with each and every listen. Beginning with a sparse and slow heartbeat, the track continues to accelerate in tempo and passion until a cool breakdown with soulful background vocals. It then begins to slow from there on, soon leading Ms. Badu's vocals to sound like they were chopped and screwed like some Southern hip-hop. It then cuts into a killer electric guitar solo from Lenny Kravitz. Finally it fades out, with Erykah singing, \"first of all/ when I tell you I love you/ don't mean I do,\" making the whole song a bit of a mystery to me. Was she simply infatuated, but not in love? \"Love of My Life Worldwide,\" a semi-remake of The Sequence's late `70s hit \"Funk You Up,\" is probably the most fun and accessible one of the bunch. Erykah, who originally began as an emcee named Apples at the tender age of fourteen, shows her skills on the mic. Queen Latifah, who has been out of the rap game for quite a while, stops by to party. Angie Stone, one third of The Sequence, puts her stamp of approval on the track and Bahamadia also shows up. The song is like a big ol' celebration on wax. The spontaneous collaboration was a great choice for the last full song on the album.As excellent as some of the EP is, the album is equally flawed. The \"World Keeps Turning\" intro and outro really weren't necessary, and are just ways to take up space, if anything. \"Woo,\" which was apparently created to replicate one of her stage-show experiments, falls terribly flat. \"The Grind\" is pretty jumbled and confusing, too. \"Bump It\" is pretty enjoyable, but I don't think all the improvising at the end of the song was necessary, even though I do love Zap Mama. \"Think Twice\" would've been one of my favorite tracks if it weren't cut short and rushed for no reason at all. It's like she was giving an intimate performance in a jazz club, and then she had to bring it to an abrupt stop after a fire started and the audience had to evacuate the building. I can take or leave the sing-songy \"Back In The Day (Puff),\" where Erykah reminisces on her childhood.The bottom line: The rough-around-the-edges and experimental Worldwide Underground is neither an EP nor a proper follow-up to the excellent Mama's Gun. Even at a short ten tracks, it has some filler and minor missteps; however, it still contains a few stellar tracks that make it worthwhile and a pretty enjoyable listen.Key tracks: I Want You, Danger, Love of My Life Worldwide.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "3   stars - Flawed, but an enjoyable listen overall.", "unixReviewTime": 1198454400, "reviewTime": "12 24, 2007"}

Premier even manages to mix a nice Method Man phrase in. \"Militia Pt 3\" keeps the intensity rollin. After this cut the next 4 cuts aren't that impressive. The thing about Gangstarr is even on the cuts you aren't feelin you still have to respect the music and the degree of difficulty. Like listening to a musical score as opposed to listening to a musical soundtrack. \"In This Life\" is once again one of those songs you feel that was destined to happen, that is DJ Premiers cool tracks and skills with Snoops voice on top. {"reviewerID": "A3T69POTR8R107", "asin": "B00008AY6B", "reviewerName": "Arch Llewellyn \"arch-l\"", "helpful": [1, 3], "reviewText": "Loved the first Malkmus record, but the art-rock tendencies that bogged down late Pavement (you remember--spacy jams, goofy chord changes, guitar god heroics) raise their head again here without a whole lot of the ol' Malkmus melody magic to help it down.  S.M.'s always had two faces, one that receives pop transmissions from the angels, another that wallows in the underground tidepools of '70s Krautrock, pysch-folk and English prog.  The dark side took over on this one.  The lyrics are also kind of light, in the clever/cutesy vein that started with \"Terror Twilight.\"  I miss the fractured poetry that made nearly everything he wrote up through \"Brighten the Corners\" so amazing.But so what? The guy's brilliant, he pretty much single-handedly saved rock in the '90s, he'll get it out of his system and give us more breathtakers on the next one.  His solo career so far reminds me a little of Dylan in the '70s, who had to get away from the \"voice of a generation\" thing with a few fluffy albums before he could get to \"Blood on the Tracks.\"  Come on, Stephen, I know you've got it in you!", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Stuck Pig", "unixReviewTime": 1048464000, "reviewTime": "03 24, 2003"}
{"reviewerID": "A6ZHB0GP9KQD7", "asin": "B00008AY6B", "reviewerName": "Pop Kulcher \"Pop Kulcher\"", "helpful": [0, 2], "reviewText": "Pop Kulcher Review:  Here's one I really wish I liked better than I do. Malkmus seems intent on making &quot;difficult&quot; albums. You really have to work at listening to this -- plod through the oblique lyrics and the unpredictable chord progressions and there's some reward to be had. But like most kids of the 70's, I already had my run-in with prog, slogging, through arduous works by Crimson and Yes and Tull and ELP; why should I have to go through the same contortions with my post-punk albums? Malkmus certainly knows how to deliver something punchy and visceral; the first two Pavement albums were near-perfect achievements: catchy and energetic, yet innovative and unpredictable. But somewhere along the line, he stopped caring so much about the sonic wallop and the hooks that gave backbone to his lyrical musings. Sure, there's still the occasional tune that you can hum along with, and his first post-Pavement solo album hinted at a return to tunefulness. But aside from a couple almost-catchy tracks, Pig Lib meanders all over the place. That's not always a bad thing. A few of the offbeat tracks here -- &quot;(Do Not Feed The) Oyster&quot; comes to mind -- manage to keep you guessing where they're going next without causing you to lose interest altogether. But on several tracks, I found myself listening to an otherwise annoying song in the hope that at some point he'd kick in with a compelling musical or lyrical phrase. Sometimes there'd be pay-off, but I don't see myself going through that effort too many more times.  [Incidentally, my version of Pig Lib came with a bonus EP which is actually a more enjoyable listen than the album itself.]", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Smart, Unique Style -- But That Doesn't Mean It's Good", "unixReviewTime": 1058227200, "reviewTime": "07 15, 2003"}

{"reviewerID": "A3KZUBM6S477EQ", "asin": "B00008H2LB", "reviewerName": "Darius Jackson \"Action Jackson\"", "helpful": [0, 1], "reviewText": "It's not THAT bad...I'm not too big on Linkin Park, but it's funny how I read all these 1 star reviews on this album, and I have yet to see WHY people hate them, it's seems to be the same message over and over again with these 1 star reviews - and that is, expressing there opinionated-rage about their beef against mainstream music, which holds no value for an arguement (music is music, get over it).While I myself don't feel to be a die-hard Linkin Park fan, I will say that I roughly enjoyed this album. I think others would feel the same way if they just open there minds. But instead, most people have this mental block for things they see on MTV. Big deal. I think one of the big +'s about Linkin Park is they CAN appeal to a wider audience (not saying they do). If you understand hip-hop, you will understand that Linkin Park's MC is actually quite good, and can flow very well. The singer Chester can scream quite intensly, and has proven with \"Breaking the Habit\" that he can sing well. Is he the best singer in rock? No, but he CAN sing. Anyone who thinks otherwise is in simple denile.I think the biggest problem with this CD is it feels rushed in some songs. It took them 3 years to come out with 36 min worth of music? Not very impressive. I think the Intro is very weak as well. 13 secs of typical movie sounds. The point to an intro is to capture the mood for the rest of the album, this fails to do that in my opinion. So therefore, it's a waste of space on the CD.In the positive scope of this album, I will say although a lot of the lyrics are whiney, it's still relatable, because every human being goes through the things that these guys talk about. It's very general and I think thats another reason why they have such a wide fan base. In my opinion, good lyrics is all about keeping it real, and speaking your mind. That's what these guys do - I feel these guys arn't faking anything, like rappers do.Some of beats on here are quite tight as well. \"Faint\" is my favorite track, leaning towards the hip-hop side. The DJ work on this CD is well thought-out. Linkin Park's DJ is good. The guitar is extremly basic, so metal heads will automatically dis-miss the guitar work, because it sounds nothing like Adam Jones or Tom Morello. Shame. Complexity shouldn't mean anything anymore. Music should be appealing to the ears, and Linkin Park does this (8 million ears listened, that IS appealing) So if this includes simple guitar riffs and strums, so be it.All in all, I don't think Linkin Park is the best thing in Rock today, but they are certainly NOT this \"horrible, corporate, mainstream, MTV, teen popin' band\" that some of these people make them out to be. Grow up - Linkin Park is keeping it real, and that's something thats rare in music nowadays.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "It's not THAT bad...", "unixReviewTime": 1049328000, "reviewTime": "04 3, 2003"}

{"reviewerID": "A2XVA2OGDYKKD", "asin": "B00008J4P5", "reviewerName": "Monsieur Valentine", "helpful": [2, 4], "reviewText": "It annoys me to see such an amateur album accumulate so much praise. Has the Rock community simply ignored White Stripes' blatant atttempt to rip off previous rock legends?This album is nothing more than a 'cut and paste' project. I don't claim to be a knowledgable historian of Rock music, which is all the more baffling.... because the tunes are instantly familiar. Every single song incorporates a collection of various samples that spans rock history. I'm not one to be dissapointed by influenced music, I realise that influence is the dynamic process of evolution and in fact I rarely complain about copyright infringement, but this album has clearly stepped over the hazy line.The first song is the only stand out song and typically the most advertised. Its the only song that comes close to being original (I think) and the lyrics are powerful enough to induce emotion. \"And if I catch you coming back my way... I'm gonna serve it to you!\"I have read countless reviews that claim this album is one of few modern creations that truly capture pure rock. That's not far from the truth, but if this is what you are looking for, then you are kidding yourself, because its simply a collage of distinguished rock moments, that any learning garage band can whip up for a school party. Turn yourself to 'The Strokes' and you will find a pure rock album pleasantly influenced but strong enough to stand on its own two feet.Oh and someone should file for a restraining order to keep that girl as far away from the microphone as possible. {"reviewerID": "ANBSW3BALFRR2", "asin": "B00008VOQM", "reviewerName": "Chet Fakir", "helpful": [3, 6], "reviewText": "At 37 minutes Fever To Tell could be considered a large EP in this the age of the CD, and while its not a bad LP debut... its just not that special.  This is a good, not great garage/punk band. I'm mean there's really not much to the music outside of a handful of fairly cool riffs played with attitude and a (very) charismatic frontwoman.  If this were a small underground or local band I'd find them enjoyable, pretty good even. They'd be fun to see live along with all the other good local bands.  But somehow the media hype machine has selected the Yeah Yeah Yeahs above a whole lot of others for some kind of annointed position in the modern rock pantheon.  And that bugs me because they're just not that good, or original. What they are is marketable, very marketable.  What could be cooler than a bassless power trio with a wild chick lead singer? Such \"alternative\" lineups (no bass player, oh my) seems to be a hot commodity these days, especially since the mostly deserved success of the dynamic duo the White Stripes.  Personally I'm waiting for a solo act consisting of a singing drummer, androgynous of course, who yodels tunes about plastic sushi and satanism while playing blast beats on a plastic garbage can with a donkeys jawbone.  Now that would be cool. Garage/psych/punk bands who blow the Yeah Yeah Yeahs away:  the Cynics, The Hives, The Carlsonics, The Capitol Years, The Make Up, Wierd War, The Sights, The Washington Social Club, not to mention The Witnesses, The Dirtbombs, the Hatebombs, and the incredible High Dials.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Overhyped and underdeveloped", "unixReviewTime": 1098662400, "reviewTime": "10 25, 2004"}

{"reviewerID": "A3FVFJ8D95E9KY", "asin": "B00008VOQM", "reviewerName": "K. Bentley \"amateur critic\"", "helpful": [5, 6], "reviewText": "The Yeah Yeah Yeahs are a NYC art-punk trio, and are probably the most recent band to be hyped by the trend-hungry press in the so-called &quot;garage rock revolution,&quot; which also contains familiar bands such as the Strokes and the White Stripes. In terms of raw energy, the YYYs certainy exemplify the garage punk sound on their debut album. It's 37 minutes of pure, unadulterated energy, wild vocals, and abrasive artsiness.Vocalist Karen O, guitarist Nick Zinner and drummer Brian Chase are explosive together; nothing better, nothing worse. Songs like &quot;Rich,&quot; &quot;Date w/ the Night,&quot; and &quot;Black Tongue&quot; show punk rock's fury in its amalgam of simple yet ear-shattering music and Karen O's frenzied vocals. Those songs are loud enough, but other songs like &quot;Tick&quot; and &quot;Pin&quot; are only more manic. However, the YYY's have not created a soind all of their own, for in some parts they rehash what proto-punk icons the New York Dolls and the Stooges (or some of Iggy Pop's solo work) have already done, as well as the attitude of &quot;riot-grrl&quot;bands like Bikini Kill and Sonic Youth's Kim Gordon. Unfortunately, Karen O also is sometimes labelled as rock's leading woman. True, she is not Avril Lavigne (thankfully), but she also has quite a ways to go before she reaches the level of Patti Smith, or even Mia Zapata. Despite the lack of total originality, the YYY's express their more admirable artistic side on the final 3 songs, starting with the minor hit &quot;Maps.&quot; Karen O's vocals are softer and more emotional, expressing a vulnerable side to her fiery presence, and even more introspective lyrics (&quot;Wait, they don't love you like I love you&quot;), and the final song &quot;Modern Romance&quot; is a slow art-punk dirge.Fever to Tell is an adequate debut for the YYY's, and while it breaks no new ground and suffers from being overhyped, and while it surrounds itself in occasional styles and trademarks of past artists and styles, the YYY's do keep today's rather bland and processed musical landscape energetic.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Adequate but Overhyped", "unixReviewTime": 1079568000, "reviewTime": "03 18, 2004"}

{"reviewerID": "AI9M4GVHAFBRU", "asin": "B00009LI14", "reviewerName": "Bubbles", "helpful": [3, 5], "reviewText": "After a stunning debut that emphasized style and vocal ability over over production, Hotel Paper emerges as a sophomore album with potential but lacking the potency of Spirit Room.  &quot;Intro&quot; seems like a waste of space to me and doesn't really add to the tone of the album.  &quot;Are You Happy Now&quot;, the first single off the album, has great lyrics and great strong vocals as well...a strong start and great song for the album.  &quot;Find Your Way Back&quot; has a more non-produced sound than even &quot;Are You Happy Now&quot; and a nice contrasting chorus section that hits into other chords...another great song.  &quot;Empty Handed&quot; starts off lightly and slowly, reminscient of older Lifehouse and I like the added instrumentals in the end...almost a twangy feeling to it but still strong and lyrically passionate.  &quot;Tuesday Morning&quot; sort of starts out like &quot;Empty Handed&quot; and has great lyrics but it just lacks a distinguishing sound.  &quot;One of These Days&quot; has a unique sound to it but the vocals could have been stronger as well, perhaps more of just a production problem, but this song definately has potential for strength.  &quot;Love Me Like That&quot; reminds me of Sheryl Crow way too much and Martina McBride but not as strong...not a great song.  &quot;Desperately&quot; sounds too similar to some of the opening tracks even though it does have a similar beat but this just isn't stand out.  &quot;Breathe&quot;...unorginal title (I can think of millions of songs titled this) and this song just isn't strong either lyrically.  &quot;Where Are You Now&quot; isn't a great stand out song either and just seems like a filler to me.  &quot;Hotel Paper&quot; surprisingly breaks the mold set up by the other songs before it but it still isn't as strong as the first half of the album.  &quot;Till I Get Over You&quot; is like the &quot;Goodbye to You&quot; of this album and has great lyrics and a melancholy type of style...but still, seems to be lacking something.  &quot;It's You&quot; is a wonderful way to end off an album, a lighter tone and feel to it and I really enjoy the vocals but it's a shame that some people won't make it this far through the middle section.  Overall, this album has some stronger parts but it's nothing like Spirit Room that had more diversity and differing sounds and lyrics.  Hotel Paper seems as though it needed some more refinement to make it stand out just like her debut...hopefully she will capitalize on the strengths of both albums when she makes another.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Maybe It Seemed Better On Paper...", "unixReviewTime": 1056412800, "reviewTime": "06 24, 2003"}

{"reviewerID": "A200C7YQJ45LRR", "asin": "B00009QGF2", "reviewerName": "Anthony Rupert \"shut up, Shut Up, SHUT UP!!!\"", "helpful": [1, 9], "reviewText": "Fountains of Wayne caught the attention of many people for two reasons: 1) the playul &quot;Stacy's Mom&quot;, and 2) the scantily clad Rachel Hunter in the video. The group scored an easy hit with that novelty (admit it) song, but if they're planning to score any more hits, I don't know if this album will do it.To be honest, &quot;Stacy's Mom&quot; is really the only song on this album that stands out. &quot;Halley's Waitress&quot; is pretty good too, but nothing else really makes the band stand out in the crowd. A lot of the songs kind of seem like calmer Blink-182-esque tracks, in that the lyrics are playful and silly yet they don't really hold your attention. But in other places the group experiments with different styles, which can make the album as a whole seem disorganized. This is especially true in &quot;Hung Up On You&quot;, which sounds like a '60s country song.Another thing about this album is that some of the songs are too brief and sometimes they end in the wrong place, which is pretty obvious considering that the album has 16 tracks yet it isn't even an hour long. Oh well, the album isn't a piece of junk though. Welcome Interstate Managers is still decent enough to play to pass the time, although there isn't really anything exciting or mind-blowing here. And all in all, I still stand behind when I placed them in my &quot;artists that won't be around next year&quot; guide.Anthony Rupert", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "3-1/2 stars -- A mixed bag", "unixReviewTime": 1078531200, "reviewTime": "03 6, 2004"}

{"reviewerID": "A1OJQAJ16T36VJ", "asin": "B00009VRDI", "reviewerName": "Anthony Humphrey", "helpful": [3, 3], "reviewText": "This album was supposed to be Ashanti's transition from hip hop newcomer to diva status, and it worked. The follow-up to her downright atrocious self-titled debut is a step in the right direction.  While anything would have been an improvement, Ashanti really impressed me, going above and beyond what was expected. With a clearly wider vocal range, a new look & hot production, Murda Inc's princess of hip hop soul shows that she is ready to prove her abilities.The opening single, \"Rock With You\", is radio-friendly hip pop at its finest and will continue to be one of your favorites. When compared to her debut's lead single \"Foolish\", you can see how much Ashanti has matured over the past 2 years. While the only track worth listening to on her debut was \"Baby\", that is definetly not the case on this record. She shows shes fed up on \"Carry On\" as well as touching on her sensitive side with tracks such as \"Sweet Baby \" & \"Rain on Me.\"The album's highlight is \"The Story of 2\", an infectious Motown influenced ballad, reminiscent of \"Loving You\", the hidden bonus track on Alicia Keys' debut Songs in a Minor. Another standout is \"I Found Loving\" which reminds me of a 1980's style smash. The album's biggest disappointment is the ridiculous interludes that do nothing but ruin the flow of the album.Ashanti proves that she has the vocal power, the staying power and the diva power to become one of the greatest artists in our generation. Her style is sexy without being trashy and she is an excellent role model for young women. Once she lost those side-burns she gained a great deal of my respect and she showcased a good deal of talent that she was unfortunatley holding back the first time.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Chapter II by Ashanti", "unixReviewTime": 1057449600, "reviewTime": "07 6, 2003"}

{"reviewerID": "A3KG9S1Y2NH6X3", "asin": "B0000AGWFX", "reviewerName": "Absolut King", "helpful": [6, 19], "reviewText": "I am not a hip hop fan, but Outkast is one of my favorite acts in music altogether.  They have always been innovative, creative, and gone against the downward spiral that hip hop has been taking over the past few years.  When I heard about the concept of Speakerboxxx/The Love Below, I thought it was an excellent idea.  Andre 3000 is one of the most underrated RAPPERS in hip hop, and Big Boi's is also very talented.  Saying this, I have never been more disappointed in an album, ever.Speakerboxxx is a decent album, but much less than I expected from Big Boi.  I always thought he was capable of dropping a classic album by himself, but unfortunately he proves that he can't.  After the masterful, socially conscious undertones that rules much of SouthernPlayalistic, I thought he would come up with something a little better than War, which is just an uninspired rant.  That song encompasses my entire feeling of Speakerboxxx: it had the foundation, but the ideas never came out as excellent songs.  Ghettomusik has the same kind of beat that made B.O.B. a classic, but lyrically it's just boring.  Tomb Of the Boom makes me feel as if I'm listening to any other southern rap record released in the past couple years.  There are some strong moments on Speakerboxxx, though.  &quot;The Way You Move&quot; is the way that the entire album should have been done:  Laid back with a pinch of Outkast soul.  Unwell, Knowing, and a track featuring Jay-Z and Killer Mike are the highlights of this disc.The Love Below is where the album just falls apart.  As much as I'd love to say that I just don't understand Andre's disc, or that I don't like this kind of music so I can't really judge it, it's simply not true.  The music he is TRYING to make is the music I love.  Funk, Soul, with a little jazz thrown in for good measure.  Unfortunately Andre just seems to be trying to be weirder than he really is.  Hey Ya is meant to be a TRL crowd pleaser, but actually ends up being extremely catchy.  Happy Valentines' Day works, and Take Off Your Cool is absolutely stunning.  But the rest is just too strange, and Dre just does not have the voice to pull something like this off.  You'll have to struggle to get through songs like Love Hater, and the beat and hook for Spread is so unbearable that you can't get through it without reaching for the skip button.  By the time you get to the excellent A Life In the Day of Andre (where he finally RAPS), you're ready to just burn the couple good songs onto the end of Speakerboxxx and throw The Love Below out the window.In the end, this is just a poorly executed album.  Maybe Andre just needed to get this kind of album out of his system, and now he can go back to doing what he does best:  being the best MC in the greatest rap group ever.Speakerboxxx:  3.5 out of 5The Love Below:  2 out of 5", "overall": 2.0, "summary": "Good idea... pulled off poorly", "unixReviewTime": 1064361600, "reviewTime": "09 24, 2003"}
{"reviewerID": "A3KKPVZ2EQQLAB", "asin": "B0000AGWFX", "reviewerName": "The archduke", "helpful": [0, 0], "reviewText": "The idea of two solo albums released together under the bands name is an intriguing one, but I'm not sure it completely worked for Outkast. A brilliant rap group, I believe that the true strength of these guys comes in the combination of their styles. Completely seperated, they are not as strong as they could have been. The more interesting of the two discs, &quot;The Love Below&quot;, is an eclectic mix of musical styles, from hip hop, r&amp;b to jazz. Andre tests the borders of his musical genre, but only to moderate success, as it seems the songs are focused on the music as opposed to the words and rapping. I feel he could have gone further in his songwriting to make this effort better. Don't get me wrong, this is still a solid CD, but I believe it could have been great with a little more perseverance. Outkast have proven themselves once again a group that is more than willing to push the envelope with their work, and they deserve the utmost respect for that. {"reviewerID": "A1IV4XBV2XEQPQ", "asin": "B0000AKOMI", "reviewerName": "Nasser Alqatami", "helpful": [4, 4], "reviewText": "Mention some of the best soul releases of the past couple of years and Kaleidoscope will indisputably be brought up.  Kelis&#65533; debut album was the masterpiece belonging to music gurus the Neptunes.  It managed to crack the market with the angry &#65533;Caught Out There,&#65533; but then disappeared with the &#65533;Good Stuff,&#65533; a track so simple it is striking.Kelis then vanished from the American charts but was greatly appreciated across the Atlantic by her British fans.  Her second effort, Wanderland, didn&#65533;t fair too well commercially, but soared sonically.  Before the Neptunes become the hot-shot producers that they are now, Kelis&#65533; first two albums were workshops for the masterminds to carve out beats that are experimental yet catchy.  There is not one track on her previous albums that does not have its moment.  They all came with attitude and spunk, which made her albums somewhat universal in the sense that the songs can be celebratory and relaxed at the same time.Now Kelis wants to crack music&#65533;s biggest market &#65533; the United States of America &#65533; and in the process, she has compromised some of her best assets.  The proof is the lead single &#65533;Milkshake,&#65533; which is a mix of assorted bland beats and an attempt at sounding sexy.  It did the job, however &#65533; &#65533;Milkshake&#65533; currently sits at number three on the Billboard Hot 100.  The album is not mediocre, yet in comparison to her past work, it&#65533;s not a standout either.  It seems that even the producers of the album noticed the missing slot, which they fixed by using a track called &#65533;Flashback&#65533; from Kelis&#65533; previous album.  Moreover, it is one of the best tracks on Tasty.&#65533;In Public&#65533; and &#65533;Trick Me&#65533; are both satisfying treats that stick to the Kelis songbook.  The songs are strong, but not as catchy as demonstrated in &#65533;Stick Up&#65533; and &#65533;Rolling Through the Hood.&#65533;There is a track that sounds like a b-side from Outkast&#65533;s &#65533;Speakertboxxx/The Love Blow,&#65533; titled &#65533;Millionaire.&#65533;  Also, &#65533;Glow&#65533; is probably the weakest Kelis song ever.However, fans do have something to satisfy their wait.  &#65533;Sugar Honey Iced Tea&#65533; is definitely tasty and &#65533;Protect My Heart&#65533; hits home with its dazzling melody.The best way to describe Tasty is that it is first-class mediocre, which means that you are getting the average from the top of the crop.  Kelis is one of the best newbies in the music scene, and since her 2000 debut, she has managed to create solid beats with minimum fluff.  However, as can be seen from the album sleeve and the swimsuit pin-up, Kelis seems to be trying to introduce herself to a new and more mainstream audience.Her mesmerizing voice is still intact and her vocals are beautiful, not because of an impressive range, but because of the warm tone it carries.  Kelis is unlikely to disappear anytime soon, however.  Tasty is a notable album, even if it is the worst of her personal catalogue.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Kelis delivers Tasty", "unixReviewTime": 1074643200, "reviewTime": "01 21, 2004"}

The liner notes with Neil's 6-page essay is a must read - and you'll read about all the trouble they had at this last show in Rio de Janeiro in front of 40,000 fans. I really have to question why RUSH felt the need to put out another 'live' recording with so few albums in between their last one (1998). Seems like everything they've EVER put out has been done with mathematical precision and state-of-the-art equipment. Through heavy winds, torential rains, an outdoor soccer stadium with no acoustics, and equipment shorting out due to being wet... and probably most importantly NO SOUND CHECK prior to the show... this project, in my opinion, was doomed from the start. Geddy's bass is overpowering, Alex's guitar is almost non-existent on many songs, and Neil's cymbals sound off - probably due to the water on his cymbals (as he stated in his article). I dig RUSH. I believe Geddy, Alex and especially Neil are master craftsman with their instruments. {"reviewerID": "A1534MBU6VJXYN", "asin": "B0000DD79B", "reviewerName": "Anthony Nasti \"Tony\"", "helpful": [42, 44], "reviewText": "Simon & Garfunkel are one of my all time favorite groups. They rank right up there with Zeppelin, Dylan, The Beatles, The Who, the Stones, Queen and all my other favorite musicians.I loved my very first S & G cd, \"The Best Of Simon & Garfunkel\". Since that collection had but a mere 20 songs and had a somewhat short running time of only 64 minutes, I felt I hadn't gottent the full extent of their work. I thought I'd get a far greater view with the two cd, 31 song \"The Essential Simon & Garfunkel\". Unfortunately, I was wrong. Why? Read on for the positives and the negatives.Positives:-You do get the most well known hits from the band. \"The Sound Of Silence\", \"Homeward Bound\", \"I Am A Rock\", \"Scarbourough Fair/ Canticle\", \"Hazy Shade Of Winter\", \"The 59th Street Bridge (Feelin' Groovy)\", \"Mrs. Robinson\", \"The Boxer\", \"Bridge Over Troubled Water\" and all the rest of the band's biggest hits are here.-A few underrated gems are included as well, such as \"Keep The Customer Satisfied\", \"So Long Frank Lloyd Wright\" and \"Baby Driver\".-Good sound quality.-Affordable enough.-Easy to locate.Negatives:-As many reviewers pointed out, several of the songs are different than the original versions, most notably \"Homeward Bound\", \"The Sound Of Silence\" and \"I Am A Rock\".-Too many live versions! If they wanted to make a far more concise S & G collection that could've perhaps been definitive, they should've put the original versions.-Neither disc fills up the eighty minute time limit. I've always preferred them together, like on \"The Best Of Simon & Garfunkel\".-Sound quality is good, but the earlier \"The Best Of Simon & Garfunkel\" is better IMO.Overall, this is a decent collection, but I feel that the single disc \"The Best Of Simon & Garfunkel\" is BY FAR a better bet. I hope to one day acquire the \"Columbia Studio Recordings\" boxed set, but until then, \"The Best Of Simon & Garfunkel\" is the best I can do.
