While I would like to report that this CD totally blew me away and makes me want to become a fan of J1, as good as the music is, I just couldn't get excited about it. It's like when you have an ice cream craving, and you go to the freezer, and there's ice cream, but only vanilla and only one scoop. It just doesn't satisfy. And although the songs are varied in theme and texture, the execution seems like typical modernist production: clean, crisp, and bland. There's just no edge to this music. The vocalist, who is capable of rough and smooth, high and low, always seems to choose the same timbre to express himself, which is good if you want redundancy, but bad if you want real emotion. I suppose my training-in-jazz ears could be part of the problem, or maybe my expectations were just too high. I don't know. The songs seems written to a formula, and the themes are not at all apparent in the lyrics or overall ambiance of the individual tunes. Without checking the title, it's impossible to say if the song is sad, happy, frustrated, in love, or what, and even after knowing the title, the feel of the song doesn't always seem to fit. {"reviewerID": "A1EQIRL8ZVZPDN", "asin": "B0030IXWH2", "reviewerName": "Rudolph Klapper \"klap4music\"", "helpful": [13, 22], "reviewText": "As an artistic effort, These Hopeful Machines is immediately inspiring and, truth be told, a bit intimidating. Clocking in a bit under two hours, the mammoth record is split into two slightly more manageable sides, although the differences between either are negligible. It's an interesting concept, and one that speaks to BT's desire to release an album as opposed to a dance record. There is an ebb and flow that's obvious from opener \"Suddenly\" to the Psychedelic Furs cover \"The Ghost in You\" that closes everything out. At times it's a rewarding experience, where all the jagged pieces fall together into a thing of seamless beauty that is as amazing for its coherence as it is for its understated complexity: check the shimmering collapse of \"The Emergency\" into the glitchy \"Every Other Way\" or the way the filthy house rave of instrumental \"The Rose of Jericho\" gracefully downshifts into new-wave rocker \"Forget Me.\" For a man of BT's talents it should come as no surprise, but it's hard to make it through a full listen of These Hopeful Machines without coming off with the impression that the record is a bit bloated, particularly much of the first and fourth tracks off the second disc, which meander about melodies and dreamy soundscapes without much of a purpose or hook.It should come as little surprise then, that amidst the typically excellent mood pieces and foot-stomping parties BT throws down, the album really succeeds on the contributions of its vocalists, from Transeau himself to guest vocalists like Rob Dickinson, Kirsty Hawkshaw, and Christian Burns. At times they make the track, as on Burns' urgent vocals on \"Suddenly\" or the delicate performance Transeau puts on \"The Ghost in You,\" which overhauls the original into an entirely new atmospheric beast. On the other hand, Hawkshaw's angelic work on \"A Million Stars\" comes off as far too airy, making the rather boring track seem like a bad Enya trance mix. Dickinson's throaty effort on \"Always,\" meanwhile gives the track a bit of a Nickelback-in-Ibiza vibe that is certainly off-putting only aided by the cheesy lyrics, although he redeems himself on the soulful, breezy \"The Unbreakable\" later on.Still, BT's true talents continue to lie in his house work, and on hard-hitting club mixes like \"The Rose of Jericho\" or the gritty synths and transcendent melodies of the bipolar \"Every Other Way,\" Transeau continues to prove he can progressive, fresh house with the best of them. While it's entertaining to see such a talent spread his wings beyond his most successful works, the uneven nature of These Hopeful Machines speaks to a scattered genius, one who is suitably proficient in everything from soft rock `n roll to fist-pumping anthems to hypnotic mood pieces, but one who still struggles to fit them all into a clear, consistent aural portrait.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "BT - These Hopeful Machines 6/10", "unixReviewTime": 1265068800, "reviewTime": "02 2, 2010"}
{"reviewerID": "AQ88FGWQOZMB8", "asin": "B0031AV72Q", "reviewerName": "Jayson Berray", "helpful": [1, 4], "reviewText": "Brian \"Danger Mouse\" Burton is probably best known as being one half of the electro-funk/soul duo Gnarls Barkley. What he's probably second best known for is being the Rick Rubin of indie music production.Whether it be Gorillaz (2005's \"Demon Days\"), The Black Keys (2008's \"Attack & Release\"), or Beck (2008's \"Modern Guilt\"), if you're looking to have success or revitalization within the genre of indie music you'd better consider working with Danger Mouse at some point.Most recently, we've seen Danger Mouse pop up with yet another \"Super Duo\". This time he's paired with The Shins' lead singer James Mercer under the name Broken Bells.Random? Yes.A good idea? Sure.This album is Broken Bells' self-titled debut and Mercer's voice seems to fit fairly well with the musical ambiance that Danger Mouse provides as both producer and performer. But Mercer's vocal style isn't distinctive enough to make his pairing with Danger Mouse a likely one in terms of the popularity that is associated with Burton these days. I guess that's why it seems random. But random is definitely not always bad.If you're looking for catchy melodies as well as poppy and laid back beats then \"Broken Bells\" is probably a good album for you. It provides a unique sound, which is always a welcomed thing no matter who you are (maybe). Even though Mercer's vocals might not be terribly distinctive they do seem to work with Burton's soulful production style, which has become well known for its throwback/psychedelic feel.I guess a possible reason the pairing of these two gentleman seems random is because after having listened to the album several times through, in some ways it feels a bit like the next Gnarls Barkley record only with a different singer. The songs aren't anywhere near as up-tempo as a lot of Gnarls Barkley songs are but given the soul/funk/R&B; tinge I halfway expected to hear Cee-Lo Green's voice at first.Usually elements of an album being considered interchangeable with something else means it's not really anything special or anything that would stand out as a classic and, to be honest, at the end of the day \"special\" or \"classic\" probably aren't terms I'd use to describe this album. Yes it's good, but probably not enough to stand the test of time. However, it's enjoyable and interesting enough to where I'll stay tuned to see what, if anything, these guys come up with next.Broken Bells' lead off single is the album's opening track, \"The High Road\". It's a good track but it seems to have fallen prey to the perils of radio. Portland radio is apparently in love with the song to the point that I already consider it to be over-played. It's to the point that when I listen to the album I usually start from track two.Distinguishable tracks:-Radio peril aside, \"The High Road\" really is a good track and is a prime example of great use of synths. Everything about the track screams that Danger Mouse was involved if you're at all familiar with his work.-\"Vaporize\" with its brooding organ sound and seemingly-unfitting-but-not acoustic guitar.-\"The Ghost Inside\" has a good beat and also has some fun handclaps, which have come to be a mainstay on any album Danger Mouse is involved in.-\"Mongrel Heart\" is about as up-tempo as the album gets which, by the point it rolls around as the second to last track on the album, is a welcomed change of pace.I'm not the biggest fan of indie music by any means, I find a lot of it to be very hit and miss, but I enjoyed this experience because it takes elements of music from the indie scene and by bringing Danger Mouse into the picture couples it with elements that make the experience a bit more interesting. I wouldn't say this is the greatest pairing since Simon & Garfunkel by any means but this album is a fun one to throw on in the car if you're spending your Saturday night cruising around town with nothing in particular to do.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Something New and Cool", "unixReviewTime": 1271116800, "reviewTime": "04 13, 2010"}

{"reviewerID": "AA6HMCJRRH83P", "asin": "B003V5PPZG", "reviewerName": "Hostile Apostle", "helpful": [0, 2], "reviewText": "Well, I've given the album a chance to sink in and it's about what I expected.  I must say, however, that the album is much shorter than its track listing would have one believe.  There are not 15 songs; instead, you are presented with about nine complete tracks and a handful of interludes consisting of ambient noise and chants.  I found it especially odd and a bit frustrating that the first two tracks alone make up a double-introduction.  There have been comparisons to a Pink Floydian-composition -- an epic, sprawling album that ties together as a cohesive piece.  There are similarities -- the sonar beeps on several tracks (reminiscent of Echoes), the fuzzy interludes that bridge the gaps between tracks, and even a track by the name of \"Empty Spaces.\"  But all comparisons aside, A Thousand Suns deserves to be listened to and fully digested to attempt any type of judgement.The first complete track, \"Burning In The Skies,\" continues where Minutes To Midnight left off.  It is an electronic ballad and every time I hear it -- not unlike several other tracks here -- I can't help but picture Transformers dancing around in my head.  This is obviously where Linkin Park has settled into as far as a comfort zone goes, but then why am I not satisfied?  Not a bad track -- actually one of the better ones -- but it still feels a bit incomplete to me.Another interlude...yes, three of the first four tracks are interludes...ugh.  Nothing even happens in this one -- it's eighteen freakin' seconds long for crying out loud!  Really?!  Guns and battle cries now emit the vibe of a war/anti-war theme...\"When They Come For Me\" is actually pretty tight and it is a relief to hear Mike Shinoda rock the mic.  Remember when this happened in every song?  Yeah, I barely do either.  Good tune though with a sick Eastern feel to it.  \"Robot Boy\" begins with and carries on with a familiar tune playing in the background.  Is that piano channeling T.I.'s \"What You Know\" in the background?  Maybe it's just me, but I can't help but picture Mr. Hahn and T.I. doing body shots off pole strippers when I hear this.  I can't really even decide if I like this one or not because I am now too distracted by the thought of dancing strippers.  While it has an epic feel and continues with the aforementioned Eastern-vibe, it is a pretty chill track and won't incite any riots; curb your enthusiasm please.Another interlude and sonar beeping...Ok, in my opinion, here is where the album truly takes off -- three bare-knuckle tracks that will even turn heads from the non-believers and those who had given up hope for LP.  \"Waiting For The End\" -- what to say about this one...I love it.  Yes, it becomes quite sugar-coated after a promising start, but I can't help but sing along with it every time it plays.  The verses have a Gorillaz feel to them -- think Plastic Beach -- before taking off into one of Linkin Park's most satisfying chorus's in recent memory.  I don't think this could be prevented from reaching mainstream radio if the studio themselves refused to release it.  \"Blackout\" is even better.  While it may not be the best, or even my favorite track (then again, maybe it is), it flat out kicks @$$ and could have passed as a Fragile-era Trent Reznor production.  It is also notable that Chester does release his blood-curdling scream (yes kids, a tiny taste of Hybrid Theory!) between staccato-laced verses on \"Blackout.\"  \"Wretched And Kings\" is a grimy hip-hop track with a reggae tinge, reminiscent of a Public Enemy joint and actually closely resembles the sound the band captured during the Meteora-era...solid track.You guessed it (interlude).\"Iridescent.\"  Hmm...I don't particularly care for this one.  Shinoda and Chester singing a boring ballad that could've been a Minutes to Midnight outtake?  No thanks.Another interlude brings us into the lead single, \"The Catalyst.\"  You love it, you hate it, or you just don't know about it.  I fit into the latter category.  Even after hearing it twenty or so times, I just don't know if I like it.  I don't go out of my way to change the radio station when it's on, but I'll skip it on my iPod in a flash, so take that with a grain of salt.  Certainly not the best track here, so hopefully that still gives hope to those timid of the \"new\" sound.The album closes with \"The Messenger,\" another ballad that recalls Chester's time spent with his first band, Grey Daze (check out \"Soul Song\").  It is a fitting, yet solemn close to an album that strives to break new ground and while they may indeed reach this coveted ground, it is not yet broken.  Is the album better than Minutes To Midnight?  Yes.  Much better?  No.  At least on A Thousand Suns, they get away from the U2-esque sound and move in a slightly new direction.  It is a step in the RIGHT direction, but I hope they continue to develop an edgier-industrial (e.g., \"Blackout\") sound moving forward (someone has to at least try and succeed Reznor, right?), though I won't hold my breath on that.  To call this album or any other LP album for that matter genre-breaking is a bit of a reach, even if there aren't many bands that can replicate their ability to compose music from clouds of static.  But I'll give them credit -- when you hear Linkin Park, there's no mistaking them for anyone else.Highlights:BlackoutWaiting For The EndWretched And KingsWhen They Come For MeBurning In The Skies", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Groundbreaking?  No, but on the right track...", "unixReviewTime": 1284508800, "reviewTime": "09 15, 2010"}
{"reviewerID": "A1DIFL0333QPEB", "asin": "B003V5PPZG", "reviewerName": "Marcus T. Brody", "helpful": [11, 17], "reviewText": "I thought Minutes to Midnight was bad.... {"reviewerID": "A17LSEN4UY4XZQ", "asin": "B003V5PPZG", "reviewerName": "M. Daneker", "helpful": [3, 4], "reviewText": "Originally known for rock/rap/techno infusion Linkin Park turned on their own style with the band driven Minutes To Midnight. Now they turn fully in the opposite direction, the band nearly vanishes in the electronic wash of A Thousand Suns; a 47 minute art piece with half of the fifteen tracks being actual songs and the rest being a collection of speeches from the likes of John Oppenheimer and Martin Luther King and connecting interludes.Approaching the record as a project you can admire the anti-establishment / anti-war theme and the scope of a record that plays as one long track with 15 parts, unfortunately the lyrics and themes often fail to mesh with the music. The first song and third track \"Burning in the Sky\" has a pop music synth sound and vocal melody clashing with the chorus \"I'm swimming in the smoke, of bridges I have burned, don't apologize, I'm losing what I don't deserve.\" A strong statement in the first song to set the tone for the record, but then the next song comes. \"When the Come for Me\" has a snappy, jazz/swing beat that draws images of a big theater stage dance number with strained rhymes \"not a monkey, will not dance, even if the beat's funky.\" There's also the horrible missteps of trying to sing in a Jamaican accent, or as if they where black rapper from south central LA, it's nearly inexcusable and far below the band.The first single, \"The Catalyst\" said it all for the record, just when the song should leap out hard and grab the listener this poppy, upbeat, drum and bass house-music synthesizer kicks in as if a different record, completely, is being played at the same time over the song. It's this type of jarring, misstep, mishmash that keeps what could have been a brilliant epic record from being just that.A Thousand Suns doesn't fail because it's a radical style change for Linkin Park, it fails because they don't know how to use the styles they are incorporating in context of lyrics and themes. There's no identity here, either of the band (which it seems is just Mike, Joe and Chester engineering and mixing samples)or of the work. A Thousand Suns is a mess of styles all slammed together into a steaming pile of ****. There's parts of this record that ring of brilliance and are worth loving, but they keep blowing it with the other parts.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Reach exceeds grasp.", "unixReviewTime": 1285804800, "reviewTime": "09 30, 2010"}
{"reviewerID": "A2ULSA0IRUE09E", "asin": "B003WTE886", "reviewerName": "Marc Cabir Davis", "helpful": [3, 6], "reviewText": "The evolution of country music into an alternate genre where its songs get radio-play has often been ridiculed - after all, we've had such pop-candy stalwarts such as Shania Twain, Carrie Underwood, and even Faith Hill to cite as examples. But Taylor Swift is a definitive example of the broadening of country music - to include influences such as rock and bluegrass, so much so that the `country' aspect of it is thoroughly diluted. It is with this palette that Swift has created \"Speak Now\", a decidedly inferior followup to her breakthrough album \"Fearless\", only because it's a very obvious sellout (much in the vein of Shania Twains \"Up\", but at least on that CD Shania had the decency to release separate albums for the pop, world, and country audiences - a feat that's never been replicated since).While \"Fearless\" wore its heart on its sleeve in an off-handed manner, \"Speak Now\" is more pointed and unnecessarily vicious. What seemed like innocent schoolgirl rants on \"Fearless\" have evolved into worrisome, even deranged complaints by a woman who is now well in her twenties. Prime amongst these is \"Dear John\" about John Mayer. Granted, I have no real fondness for Mayer either as a musician or as a personality of any sort, but how anyone could deserve such an accusatory track dedicated to them is beyond me. Ironically, this is the best track on the entire album - from a musical perspective - and if you can ignore the `woe is me' lyrics, there is much to enjoy here (let us pretend not to notice the absolute lack of chord progression on this song, but then again, any musician will tell you that all of Swifts songs are written in the `key of flat', so no surprises there).The innate issue with an album of this sort is that you get into it expecting more of the same that you saw on her earlier work, but the sheen has worn off, and the results aren't exactly pretty. Lead single \"Mine\", which seemed to me a stellar first single especially due to its lyrics on the chorus, ironically stalled at No. 2 on the Country Charts and didn't give Taylor the No. 1 Billboard Country Songs ribbon that she'd wanted. It was widely expected that this song would do that, but it didn't. Second single \"Back to December\" is interesting only because Swift appears to be taking the blame on this (rather than constantly blaming everyone else, which, lets be honest, is her musical forte!), but the verse-chorus-verse here is rather listenable and you might find yourself singing along to this on the radio. However, for every listenable track here, there are tons of rather poorly constructed and ill-performed numbers that go literally nowhere. \"Mean\" for example is meant to address a particular media journalist but ends up as rather tacky and in sad taste. The same can be said of the faux-rock mood of \"The Story of Us\" which was a very weak melody to begin with. These problems were not apparent on \"Fearless\" where even random album tracks such as \"Youre not sorry\" could have been potential hit singles.The other issue is that \"Speak Now\" is front-loaded with all its potential hits and the `big songs', leading to the album falling to pieces in the second half. This is unfortunate because they were really onto something with the first half, at least in terms of scoring some radio airplay or replays on CD. I cant imagine anyone wanting to listen to \"Innocent\" (her very shoddy critique of the entire Kanye West episode) more than once, and \"Never Grow Up\" is just too easy. If you were expecting Swift to bring her A game and revolutionize country music, this is not the album you should be looking at. A quick glance at some other reviews will all give added points to packaging rather than quality. For example, one reviewer calls this the `best packaged CD of the last ten years' because of the cover art, inclusion of lyrics, and superior artwork. Point noted, but honestly, aren't we supposed to judge a music CD based on the actual music rather than the packaging? Or is that the state of current country music where an album cover makes the CD get an extra star? The last two songs on this album, especially \"Long Live\", are very much culled from demos and quickly recorded - and the impact they make is just as temporary and fleeting.The Deluxe Edition of this CD gets you six bonus tracks (3 new songs, two acoustic versions and a remix). \"Superman\", while interesting, should have made the lead edition of the album instead of the Deluxe as its obviously leaps and bounds over anything else on the Deluxe bonus CD. However, if you try comparing this to \"Fearless\", you will find that the deluxe edition is nowhere as great as that one (remember it contained tons of videos on the bonus DVD as well as some killer bonus tracks). Still, I suppose the effort is appreciated. \"Speak Now\" debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 Albums Chart, and broke records as it sold a million copies in the first week. Sales-wise, that is extremely impressive, but its not quite deserved, I think. There are ideas here, thoughts with some backbone, but their delivery is just not up to the mark, and while Taylor as a vocalist has definitely made strides (check out her crystal clear voice on \"Dear John\", which remains the album highlight), she needs to record better material. Also, this album would have been a whole lot better had they paid more attention to the entire second half of the record, which to me is virtually unlistenable. For those of you who think that comparisons to \"Fearless\" are uncalled for, well, it did win Album of the Year at the Grammys, so that's saying something, and does raise the benchmark pretty high. \"Speak Now\" just can't reach those heights though.Taylor Swift remains a reasonably talented singer (though not a country singer), and I must say that if I had to compare her two other contemporary country singers - Carrie Underwood & Miranda Lambert, she comes across as third on the list. Carrie's last album \"Play On\" is definitely notches better than \"Speak Now\" (hey, at least it was a `country' album), but Miranda Lambert currently rules the country roost for me with 2010's spectacular \"Revolution\". Comparing that exceptional album to Swifts new one is like comparing Chateaubriand steak to a Kit-Kat. Swift is out of her league on that one. But, shes still young and has a decent voice, so lets hope she finally records a proper country album some day (like perhaps \"Theres More Where That Came From\" by Lee Ann Womack. Now that's country!)Three Stars. An average effort at best; and if you strip away the media-machine and PR, the music just doesn't cut it.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Dismembered : Taylor Swift takes a Chainsaw to the Country Music Genre", "unixReviewTime": 1295481600, "reviewTime": "01 20, 2011"}
{"reviewerID": "A3R8PXSFGY9MC2", "asin": "B003YK42LQ", "reviewerName": "Spider Monkey", "helpful": [1, 2], "reviewText": "I read some real glowing reviews of `Come Around Sundown' in the music press and eagerly bought my copy and I am disappointed to say that whilst this is a solid KOL album, it is also very much a formulaic affair. The sound is very reminiscent of their previous album and each track sounds very much like the next. The exception to this would have to be `Back Down South' which sounds individual enough to stand out, but which isn't the strongest of tracks. `Radioactive' has been chosen for the first single and it is a good choice as it has some decent driving drums and guitars to keep things moving along, but it hasn`t got much else going for it. This all sounds quite negative, and I don't mean it to, as this is a very good album. {"reviewerID": "A17814AD8EWTN4", "asin": "B0048LDTKK", "reviewerName": "------------- \"------------\"", "helpful": [13, 19], "reviewText": "There are so many reasons why I call R. Kelly the undisputed King Of R&B.; One of them being the fact that the man's talent is unmatched in this ever changing music industry. Weather we are talking about his exceptional vocals, or his amazing swagger, or his ability to make every track he's a part of his own track. Another reason I call him the King of R&B;, is because he is a true musician in every sense of the word. He writes, produces, sings, and plays instruments on all of his own records. He rarely lets other people produce or write for him, with the exception of his last album Untitled, and his '98 record R. And not only does he produce/write the majority of his own music, he also does so for other artists ranging from the legendary Michael Jackson to the lesser know R&B; singer Joe. And another thing that has to be acknowledged about R.Kellys resume, is that he has been able to maintain relevance for almost 20 years, and not only maintain that relevance, but also dominate the R&B; genre for almost that entire time. He helped change R&B; into what it is today. Without R. Kelly, there wouldn't be any Usher's, or Chris Brown's, or Trey Songz's. R. Kelly paved the way for all of those artists, and not only that but he's also sold 40 million records and had a over 20 hit singles along the way. Needless to say, R. Kelly is easily the best modern day R&B; singer of our time. He's like the new Marvin Gaye, which R. Kelly considers Marvin to be one of his biggest influences, and some would argue that Kells is better. He's won Grammy's, Soul Train Awards, Lifetime Achievement Awards, graced covers of several magazines, produced his own mini movie... I mean honestly, what has the guy not done in his 20 year stint in this entertainment business?One of the things that I admire most about R. Kelly, is his diversity. He is such a unique artist that has so many different sides to his musical genius that it almost make it hard to tell what kind of artist he truly is. I mean obviously he is a bonafide R&B; singer, and there is no doubt about that. But the thing I love about R. Kelly, and this is probably one of the biggest reason's why he's been able to stay relevant all these years, is that he is always changing. And I don't know if \"Changing\" is really the right word im looking for, but he is always tweeking and adding different styles to his craft. Like I said there are so  many sides to R. Kelly's artistry, there's the partying \"Ignition\" and \"Fiesta\" R. Kelly, there's the club goer \"I'm A Flirt\" and \"Supaman High\" R. Kelly, there's the sentimental \"I Wish\" and \"I'm Your Angel\" R. Kelly, there's the inspirational \"I Believe I Can Fly\" and \"World's Greatest\" R. Kelly, there's the Thug \"Double Up\" and \"Playa's Only\" R. Kelly, and my personal favorite baby making time \"Echo\" and \"Bump and Grind\" R. Kelly... And of course there's the strait up, what I like to call the Loverman side of R. Kelly, which was mostly shown on his Chocolate Factory album, and now Love Letter as well... Like I said, the man is very versatile...Which is why he is probably my favorite artist of all time. It's because every one of his albums is different from the last or has a completely different theme than the last. R. was his radio ready breakthrough record, TP-2.com was his strait up baby maker, Chocolate Factory was a love album, Happy People/U Saved Me was stepper's music/gospel, Double Up was a hip hop record, and Untitled was a collage of contemporary R&B.; Now I'm not saying that those album's are strictly in those themes, obviously it can vary a little bit, but generally speaking his albums do tend to have a specific theme for the most part.Now if I had to compare Love Letter to any of his previous albums, it would be without a doubt in my mind compared to the love album Chocolate Factory. As a matter of fact, after the first listen to Love Letter, I was calling it the poor man's Chocolate Factory, because sonically and lyrically, both of the album's have the same warm, lovey, romantic vibe. With Love Letter he does have a strong throwback 60's/70's soul vibe, which was only sprinkled on Chocolate Factory, where as with Love Letter the throwback vibe does tend to dominate a little more, which is why the album is garnering strong reviews most likely. The problem with Love Letter, and what's keeping it from being a classic like Untitled, is that although it is nice and refreshing to hear that 70's  throwback style today among all the pop/r&b; thats dominating the charts today, Love Letter does drag a little bit and at times kind of starts to sound bland and a bit out dated. I'm not saying its a bad album or even sub par, but it's not one of his best albums. I understand what he was trying to accomplish with this album, but there's just not many songs at all on the album that have that aggressive, carnal tones that have made R the legend he is today. R. Kelly has always been known for his raunchy overly sexual baby makers, which is where he most successful and most dominant. And for me personally, the baby makers are my personal favorites from R. Kelly, because he does them the best...But there is little to none of that on Love Letter. Much like Chocolate Factory, on Love Letter the song's that do have any sort sexuality, which isn't much at all, but when there is that little bit of sexuality it's more in the form of romance than the typical raunchy style R. Kelly brings most of the time. Like on loud and roaring \"Taxi Cab\" or the mellow slow jam \"Lost In Your Love\", which are both standouts. But where R. Kelly really dominates on this album is the throwback soul slow jams, like on the smooth title track, and the old school \"When A Woman Love\", and on the groovy slow jam \"Number One Hit\", he compares his the love of his woman to that joy of a number one hit. \"Number One Hit\" sounds sooooo much like a track from Chocolate Factory that I almost wondered if it might have been from the Chocolate Factory sessions, the way he just smoothly glides across the mellow instrumental. It's for sure one of the standout cuts from the album, along with the catchy desperate I Want You Back anthem \"Radio Message\". And Mr. Kelly also does a pretty great cover of MJ's \"You Are Not Alone\", which isn't surprising since he wrote and produced the track for MJ. Overall, it's not a surprise that this album is getting the great reviews it is, and it will likely be looked at as a comeback record for R. Kelly even though he has never really left, as his last album Untitled was also great, but it was also a completely different style. The thing that will win a lot of people over with this record is it's soulfulness, and its throwback 70's soul vibe, which is rare these days from contemporary R&B; singers...It's not his best record, and I definitely do prefer Untitled over this one, but it is still a strong album...But if anyone can pull off this type of style change, it would be the extremely versatile Mr R. Kelly!Grade:C+", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "R. Kelly - Love Letter (3.5 stars)", "unixReviewTime": 1292457600, "reviewTime": "12 16, 2010"}

{"reviewerID": "A2TX79GR278JMA", "asin": "B004EQCO5U", "reviewerName": "P. Opus", "helpful": [2, 2], "reviewText": "After listening to Sam Beam's newest release I was pretty surprised to see all the negative reviews posted online.  While this recording certainly reflects a deviation in style from Mr. Beam's past work, it isn't as downright terrible (at least to my ears) as some of the Iron & Wine fans make it out to be.  The Iron & Wine project has been an evolving thing, gradually transforming from meditative solo acoustic guitar pieces with very personal lyrics (Creek Drank the Cradle, still my favorite of Mr. Beam's recordings and probably always will be) through to the more sonically diverse and somewhat experimental Shepherd's Dog. Here he has gone in yet another different direction, incorporating a more heavily electronica-tinged sound and some gospel influences into the mix. More than anything, this recording shows an artist willing to grow and take on new ideas.  Some of these songs are downright catchy, and in some ways it's the most purely fun album Sam Beam has released.  That said it doesn't have the depth of his earlier work and sometimes the electric sounds can grow a bit tiresome and seem like distracting  \"bells & whistles\" rather than anything necessarily intrinsic to shaping the songs themselves. When it all hangs together it works quite nicely however and I find myself coming back to the better tracks now & again.  Not the album I'd recommend as an introduction to Iron & Wine, and not something I'd expect to convert many new fans, but still an enjoyable and sophisticated musical experience that doesn't seem so out of place in Mr. Beam's constantly expanding repetoire.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "3.5 Stars: A nice experiment", "unixReviewTime": 1313020800, "reviewTime": "08 11, 2011"}

In the case of First Impressions of Earth, neither group were particularly pleased, as evidenced by the band's fervent attempt to recapture the magic of their earlier releases on their latest LP, Angles.To cut down to the core, this record is all surface, no substance. Blue Spotted-Tail is wonderful, mostly because of the simplicity of the acoustic guitar and melody line. But the problem for me, despite the clear effort that's gone into this disc, is that it just doesn't hang together very well as an album. {"reviewerID": "A3KJ6JAZPH382D", "asin": "B004UBB3KQ", "reviewerName": "Tim Brough \"author and music buff\"", "helpful": [1, 2], "reviewText": "The debut by Foster The People rides mainly ion the skills of lead singer/songwriter Mark Foster, who has found the way to homogenize the sound of indie and dance for his \"Torches.\" He's got a knack for ear-worm choruses, already made unavoidable by the all-summer-long pervasiveness of \"Pumped Up Kicks,\" and \"Don't Stop.\" The music has an effervescence to it, which is interesting if you consider that \"Kicks\" is a song about a shooting spree.That is what makes \"Torches\" both promising, interesting and frustrating. Mark sings in a Bee Gees helium voice, which keeps the music buzzy and floaty. There isn't much by way of depth, but there's loads of tart candy to be had. The opening of \"Helana Beat\" had me thinking Donna Summer and popped up on my I-Pod's random play. There's no way to deny it, \"Foster The People\" are a solid pop band that is currently rolling in some hipster cred. The question is going to be if they can lift themselves to the pop creativity of, say, Adam Levine/Maroon 5 or if \"Pumped Up Kicks\" is this year's MGMT and \"Kids.\"", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Foster the Hooks", "unixReviewTime": 1325635200, "reviewTime": "01 4, 2012"}

{"reviewerID": "A18D87U8CUN0F9", "asin": "B006UFH4N0", "reviewerName": "Jason Harrington \"Trucker Hater Magazine\"", "helpful": [1, 5], "reviewText": "I want to like this more, since I paid real money and got the packaging and all, but really the packaging is not worth it, since it's dominated by negative space, not detailed images that provide new things to notice. You have to read some articles to know that the objects in the graphics are mostly related to the guitarist's dad or grandpa or whatever from the military, etc. Sorry to sound disingenuous, but I just think this back-story has little to do with the content of these songs, personally.On to the music...if only I could, but unfortunately there are more distractions. For someone like myself who loves music with electronic beats, I find it irritating that there is no visible drum machine in their stage rig. For a guitarist who co-founded the come-and-gone sub-genre of metalcore, he should know well the perils of making a new trend that later turns hollow and meaningless in the hands of bands that breathe in your influence and exhale something less than worthy.For real this time...no, still more distractions: The singer's look seemed like her own interesting style when they first came out. Now it feels more like just another calling card to summon fan art and branding for merchandising purposes. Really, clips of them live make me so excited when I'm preparing to watch them, but afterward I have a stomach ache and feel like a sucker for the next big craze. This is not dangerous music anymore like it was at first. It takes more than references to demons and what not for that to happen.The music: I'm done. I will still listen to this on occasion, but I will brag about it to no one and turn it off when someone enters the room. What happened to the overblown beats and experimental lyric structures? I feel stupid now for hyping them up when they first came out. I mean, I bought this at Target the day it came out. I don't feel good about doing that. I should have bought some other corporate crap like Kanye West.I mean, Crystal Castles are on a major label now; why do I not feel gut-rot from their sugary goth-pop? Maybe because it's hella legit, from the art to the stage to the lyrics to the style. I'm going to see Crystal Castles live next week, and I bet there are no frat boys there. Kesler \"Jenell & Robert Kesler\"", "helpful": [0, 0], "reviewText": "Alabama Shakes filter through the Atlanta woods like evening fog creeping across the fallen leaves ... and before you know it you're ankle deep in spooky wonder. That being said, there are a fair number of intensity impassioned heartbreak filled numbers that convey a trance-like depth and melancholy that had me wondering how anyone could understand my distress so well.Come on ... give `em a spin, what've you got to lose?Review by Jenell Kesler", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Alabama Shakes - Boys & Girls", "unixReviewTime": 1352764800, "reviewTime": "11 13, 2012"}

{"reviewerID": "A34F7JSAHJG0ZV", "asin": "B007HRXJVG", "reviewerName": "John D. Pride", "helpful": [2, 3], "reviewText": "Bethany Cosento seems to be a simple person. She shops at Target, likes bad reality TV shows and watches light comedy at home. This may go some distance in explaining the overall banality  (some might say \"simplicity\") of her lyric writing over the course of two full-length releases. The melodies are familiar and catchy - you may find yourself swearing you just heard the song that's playing, earlier on the same record. That said, I am enjoying this record quite a bit.The slight beefing up in production (the hyperbole from fans about this is much ado about nothing) is a plus, and just in time; I think if I hear one more indie duo with a female singer sporting surf guitars, hazy vocals and reverb, I'll lose it. The fact is, The Beach Boys' \"I Love California\" approach has always defined the tone and attitude of Best Coast's recordings. This is the sound of a young woman who is having fun in a really, really fun place to be when you're 25 years old.This record is as much who Best Coast is as their last. Sure, the words don't add up to much besides \"we've got the sun, we've got the bay, we've got the waves....why would anyone want to be anywhere else?\". {"reviewerID": "A14GK0E64J0WAS", "asin": "B00BB22GQM", "reviewerName": "Paul Allaer", "helpful": [4, 8], "reviewText": "As a fan from the very beginning, Vampire Weekend's  2008 self-titled debut album is for me one of the more accomplisdhed debut albums in the last 10 years. And the second album \"Contra\" (from 2010) was pretty darn good too. Now, after 3+ years away, finally comes the band's highly anticipated third album.\"Modern Vampires of the City\" (12 tracks; 43 min.) starts off with an immediately pensive, piano-led \"Obvious Bicycle\". The energy level goes up a notch or two with \"Unbelievers\". Track 4 \"Diane Young\" (1st single) is the best track on the album for me, reminding me of the band's earlier output. But after that it's mostly back to mid-tempo tunes (\"Don't Lie\", \"Everlasting Arms\", \"Ya Hey\"), or outright slow songs or ballads, Vampire Weekend-style of course (\"Hannah Hunt\", \"Hudson\", \"Young Lion\"). There are a couple more flashes of the band we used to know late into the album on \"Finger Back\" and \"Worship You\".I bought this album last week, sound unheard, and purposefully did not post my review right away, as I wanted to make sure I wasn't missing anything. Now a week on, I can tell you that my feelings for this album have not improved. I scroll thrugh the many 5 star reviews posted on here, and I'm thinking to myself \"did we listen to the same album\"? I would sum up the situation as follows: listen to the opening tracks of the three VW albums one after another: \"Mansard Roof\" from VW, \"Horchata\" from Contra, and \"Obvious Bicyle\" from this album, and you'll know all you need to grasp the differences: Vampire Weekend has matured &lt;gasp>, yes the dreaded maturity has done it again. If you like the fun, breezy, clever sounds from the first two albums, you will likely be disappointed with the new album, as the musical landscape on \"Modern Vampires of the City\" is MILES away from the previous albums. Buyer beware!*UPDATE* (Oct '13) I saw Vampire Weekend in concert this past weekend at the Corona Capital festival in Mexico City. They brought a tremendous 75 min. set, mixing new and old tunes, and I must say that the new songs resonate live much better than on the album. The massive crowd just ate it up. If you have a chance to see them live, do not miss them!", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Goodbye fun songs, hello \"maturity\"", "unixReviewTime": 1369008000, "reviewTime": "05 20, 2013"}
{"reviewerID": "ADH0O8UVJOT10", "asin": "B00BB22GQM", "reviewerName": "StormJH1", "helpful": [81, 111], "reviewText": "It's clear that Vampire Weekend wanted to go in a different direction with this album.  Many people will reward them for that, citing the \"evolve or die\" argument.  But if you were a fan of Vampire Weekend's first two albums (as I am) and excited for this new release (as I was), there's the potential for massive disappointment here.My primary source of disappointment (and the reason I decided to become the first 3* reviewer) is the total absence of notable guitar work on the album.  As a guitar player, I'm obviously biased, but I feel like Vampire Weekend had a few hallmarks to their sound that make them identifiable as a band.  One of those is the \"faux harpsichord\" progressions, which still appear on this album.  They also have some beautiful piano parts layered underneath Ezra's vocals.  But the guitar riffs - a variety of vintage, almost \"surf\"-like undertones - are almost completely gone, and that was one of my favorite aspects of Vampire Weekend's music.  Take virtually any notable VW song (A-Punk, Oxford Comma, Holiday, Cousins, etc.), and there is heavy guitar work that makes up the identity of those songs.  (The beautiful piano work on \"Taxi Cab\" would be a notable exception to this rule).  That VW has chosen to virtually eliminate guitar from the formula and become more a piano/electronic band doesn't make them \"bad\", but takes away an important element of what made them great.As a secondary complaint, I would note that there's real lack of energy in this album.  It reminds me a lot of all the things wrong with U2's \"No Line on the Horizon\" - excellent musicianship, but ask yourself an important question: \"Had this been the FIRST album from this band, would anyone have noticed them through the crowd?\".  It's possible to make a \"darker\" album without compromising the energy and formula that made your band appealing in the first place.My view appears to be a minority opinion, but I thought the first two albums were 5* all the way.  I'm 31 and I didn't consider them to be \"immature\" records in any sense.  I will stick with the album to see if it \"grows\", but normally when you hope for an album to \"grow\" on you, you're basically waiting for it to become something it's not.There's an assumption out there that individual bands need to \"grow up\" with us and become more serious and contemplative with us, as we presumably are also doing with age.  I don't agree with that.  I think that notable bands and artists \"stand\" for something, and allow you to seek that out if that's a mood or sentiment you want to experience.  It's possible for a band to start as something and become something else.  U2 has been everything from a Christian band to an Electronic/Dance band.  But if you want \"something different\", nobody's putting a gun to your head and forcing you to play Vampire Weekend.  Summers in Cape Cod are nowhere to be found on \"Modern Vampires\", and I kind of miss it.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "If you like Vampire Weekend, you may or may not like this", "unixReviewTime": 1368576000, "reviewTime": "05 15, 2013"}

{"reviewerID": "A1HWMU2XORHEI4", "asin": "B00CUKTG2Q", "reviewerName": "J. Hubner \"hubner73\"", "helpful": [20, 23], "reviewText": "How many of you like me were enamored with Franz Ferdinand back in 2004? It's hard to describe, but something about that debut album lit a post-punk fuse in me. I'd just begun listening to Gang of Four and had dabbled in The Jam as well. These cats were just the right modern take on a untouchable music noise that I was just beginning to love. I imagined Ray Davies sounding like \"Michael\", \"Darts Of Pleasure\", \"This Fire\", and the excellent \"Come On Home\" had he been born 20 years later. Alex Kapranos had this mix of snarky ambiguity and genuine sad sackery in his vocals and lyrics on that first album that I thought for sure they'd be spanking other revivalists of the same ilk in years to come. So I wasn't completely correct in that assumption. But I wasn't completely incorrect. You Could Have It So Much Better had these Scottish Orange Juice disciples putting their dance shoes away so they could show some rock machismo. Then 2009s Tonight: Franz Ferdinand was a mix of rock n' roll noise, dance floor strut, and Moog freakouts. Most folks in-the-know would say both of the follow-ups were sorta failures(records sales say differently), at least artistically. I'm not in-the-know.  I'm just a schlub from the Midwest that likes his beer strong, his pizza drowned in cheese, and his dance rock boogie-inducing. Franz Ferdinand have been known to be a bit bitey, rather cheesy at times, and can make this middle-aged white guy want to strut his wares more often than not. Well, after nearly breaking up, Franz Ferdinand have returned 4 years later with Right Thoughts, Right Words, Right Action, and while not breaking new ground have made the best with the fertile soil they've been working for nearly 10 years.\"Right Action\" opens up with a familiar funky groove and a Kapranos sneer that tells you we're back in sweaty pub territory. It's a less venomous version of \"Take Me Out\", sped up and some farfisa organ thrown in for good measure. \"Evil Eye\" has a great 80s dance beat to it, with a sound not unlike Madness doing a spy theme. Kapranos and company have taken the great production values of Tonight: Franz Ferdinand and the grittier songs of their debut to make something that sounds crisp and tight, but not overproduced. \"Love Illumination\" is the single and while it's got some cool fuzzy guitar and even a horn section the track doesn't really go anywhere. \"Right Action\" would've been a great single choice. But like I said, I'm just a schlub. \"Stand On The Horizon\" is a nice little ballad that doubles as a dance floor disco burner. \"Bullet\" churns and burns but sorta sits in one gear, but it's got a great chorus.We get a lot of the same throughout the rest of this album. There's moments that shine, and others that sorta sit and wait for your approval. It's sorta sad for me, as in my eyes the Franz Ferdinand that won me over with their angular riffs and snarky storytelling don't need anyone's approval. As long as they do what they do best they'll be just fine. Right Thoughts, Right Words, Right Action isn't going to floor you. I'll admit it, Franz Ferdinand are a guilty pleasure. But guilty pleasure or not, they shouldn't be written off. There's enough here for you to dig your teeth into. And hey, you can go ahead and shake what the Lord gave ya. {"reviewerID": "A3GX1VI6FCV0IG", "asin": "B00GZAHGI8", "reviewerName": "Lypo Suck", "helpful": [4, 7], "reviewText": "Whereas in the past Dum Dum Girls mined a sound that was clearly inspired by the Primitives' earlier work and shambling c86 groups like the Shop Assistants (with a bit of a 60s girl group vibe thrown in), with Too True they've gone for a slicker vibe that seems to parallel the sort of \"path to maturity\" some 80s indie/alternative bands took in the later half of that decade, going from jagged, low-fi indie sketches to a more polished, lush sound. As a result, Too True readily brings to mind albums like Automatic by Jesus and Mary Chain, the Primitives' second album Pure, Pop Said... by the Darling Buds, and whatever the Divinyls were doing around that time. The drum machine is an obvious late 80s reference that supplies a mechanical feel typical of that era, while thick, fuzzed-out bass and guitars ranging from jangly to scratchy to chorus-y are all quite reminiscent of albums like Automatic and Pure. Do you remember some of the songs that were in heavy rotation on your local alternative radio station in 1988-89? That's exactly what they're going for here.But how are the tunes? While I can't really say there's a bad song in the bunch, per se, only a few of them really stand out as being particularly memorable or unique. \"Evil Blooms\" is one of the more tastefully catchy standouts, with a pleasantly lush arrangement, while \"Too Good To Be True's\" main melody vaguely recalls the chorus of Echo and the Bunnymen's \"Killing Moon\", albeit sped up and in a different key. The cool, steadily rocking \"Rimbaud Eyes\" reminds me a bit of whatever Darling Buds or Divinyls songs were being played on alternative radio stations in 1988, as does \"In The Wake Of You\". Maybe they should've done covers of \"Let's Go Round There\" and \"Pleasure and Pain\" to drive the point home. It's a nice enough album, but I can't escape the feeling that they're spending a little too much time copping this very specific late 80s pose, and not enough time crafting truly memorable, distinctive, resonant melodies. As a result, the whole thing seems a bit style over substance. They've definitely got potential, but they're just not quite taking things as far as they could compositionally, which to be honest, is kind of what I've been saying about them all along.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "Nice, but a bit style over substance", "unixReviewTime": 1392163200, "reviewTime": "02 12, 2014"}
{"reviewerID": "A3A1JYOG384DRP", "asin": "B00HUAP0NK", "reviewerName": "Lawrence R. Sutton \"love music\"", "helpful": [0, 1], "reviewText": "Horrible  Quilty  can  hardy  hear  it  !!!!!", "overall": 1.0, "summary": "Stinks.........", "unixReviewTime": 1404259200, "reviewTime": "07 2, 2014"}
{"reviewerID": "ALND45MWBGUQS", "asin": "B00HZJH9BC", "reviewerName": "Lunar Boulevard", "helpful": [18, 22], "reviewText": "After nearly four years The Hold Steady have finally graced us with their sixth album, Teeth Dreams. There's no doubt that this has been a long time coming and the end result is somewhat satisfying but far less interesting than some of their previous work.The LP opens promisingly, with lead single \"I Hope This Whole Thing Didn't Frighten You\" kicking things off in high gear. It's a solid rock tune, though for some reason Craig Finn's voice sounds distorted on the chorus. It's distracting and pulls you out of the song, a common problem that occurs frequently on Teeth Dreams. His unique vocals are constantly tweaked and laden with unnecessary effects that don't compliment the songs in any meaningful way. \"Spinners\" is one of the album's best cuts, a pop/rock tune that wouldn't sound out of place on a Counting Crows record, courtesy of jangley guitars and Finn's trademark storytelling. It's a solid start to the album and a worthy addition to the band's catalogue. It's a shame the rest of the album rarely scales these same heights.The next few tracks are a mixed bag of distorted noise and wavering melodies. \"The Only Thing\" is decent, if somewhat forgettable. \"The Ambassador\" gives the record some much-needed breathing room and has traces of previous ballads like \"Lord, I'm Discouraged\", yet doesn't do much to really distinguish itself in spite of this promise. The soft piano is a nice touch and it's an element that would have been well-served by being included more frequently on the album. \"On with the Business\" also fails to really stand out, a mediocre rock tune that unfortunately feels too much like a throwaway tune. \"Big Cig\" steers things back on course. It has just the right amount of lyrical intrigue and upbeat energy to make it worthwhile. Add to that one of the album's only big guitar solos and it all comes together wonderfully. \"Wait Awhile\" is a serviceable rock number while also feeling like a weaker version of \"Spinners\". Unfortunately it's too derivative to really stand on its own. \"Runner's High\" follows a similar path, a loud rocker that never really builds to anything spectacular.The last two tracks are where the album really comes around. The acoustic \"Almost Everything\" is wonderful, a bold track that makes me wish the rest of the album could have been sprinkled with this kind of diversity. The nine-minute closer \"Oaks\" wraps things up nicely and it once again brings much-needed diversity and laid-back atmosphere to the album. It never feels its length and harkens back to the classic sound that so many of us love about this band.Teeth Dreams is neither great nor horrible; rather, it straddles the line and offers a few tremendous moments with a lot of passable ones. Finn's voice is too distorted with various echo effects to ever really connect and his storytelling, while still strong, feels more passive this time without strong music to really back it up. The gorgeous and energetic melodies of previous releases are largely absent, replaced by noisy yet clumsy arrangements. The departure of keyboardist Fran Nicolay has still left a massive hole in the band that has yet to really be filled. The Hold Steady were always a rock band that could think outside the box and transcend labels; here they seem to be comfortable in its boundaries. The group is capable of so much more and after four years we're left with a loud, raucous effort that comes off as more forced and less playful.This album is simply lacking the fun that made previous efforts so engrossing and memorable. Ultimately Teeth Dreams is all bark and very little bite.", "overall": 3.0, "summary": "A Muddy and Mixed Experience", "unixReviewTime": 1395705600, "reviewTime": "03 25, 2014"}
